questions.text: Fibroid uterus may present with all of the following features except _______
questions.solution:
Menstrual abnormalities in fibroid include menorrhagia and metrorrhagia and not amenorrhea.

Menstrual symptoms of fibroid includes:

  • Menorrhagia, polymenorrhoea, metrorrhagia, continuous or postmenopausal bleeding
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Infertility, recurrent abortions
  • Pain
  • Pressure symptoms
  • Abdominal lump
  • Vaginal discharge

questions.text: A 40-year-old​ patient presents to the OPD with complaints of dysphagia. A barium swallow was performed and is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Barium swallow showing a smooth filling defect is suggestive of esophageal leiomyoma.

Leiomyomas are the most common solid benign tumors of the esophagus. They are usually asymptomatic but large tumors may cause dysphagia or discomfort. The tumors arise in the muscularis propria and are usually found in the mid to distal esophagus.

Barium swallow shows a smooth filling defect. On endoscopy, leiomyoma appears as a round protrusion into the lumen with smooth, normal mucosa. Preoperative biopsy or EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is relatively contraindicated as the consequent scarring will increase the chance of breaching the mucosa during enucleation.

Patients with small, asymptomatic lesions are followed up. Symptomatic and large lesions may be enucleated with a VATS approach. Endoscopic resection with the creation of a submucosal tunnel for leiomyomas up to 5.5 cm can be performed.

Other options

Option C: In carcinoma esophagus, barium study shows irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female was brought by her mother as she has not had her menarche. On examination, she has a short stature, a webbed neck, a low hairline at the back of the neck, and widely spaced nipples. There is no growth of axillary or pubic hair.  Which of the following is the cause for amenorrhea in this patient?
questions.solution:
The cause of amenorrhea in this patient is primary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. 

Primary amenorrhea refers to the failure of onset of menstruation, beyond the age of 16 years regardless of the development of secondary sexual characteristics. This patient's clinical picture of amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, low hairline at the back of the neck, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome.

The pathophysiology in Turner's syndrome is primary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism where there is oocyte atresia and the replacement of ovaries by fibrous streaks. This causes a decrease in serum estrogen levels which by negative feedback to cause a rise in Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), FSH, and LH (gonadotropic hormones) as seen in this patient. Hypogonadism with a rise in gonadotropic hormones is known as hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Secondary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism is seen in damage to the gonads as seen post-chemotherapy, radiation, infection, or in autoimmune disorders.

questions.text: A patient comes to your clinic with a complaint of multiple episodes of loose watery stool for 3 days.  Which of the following is the most common viral cause of diarrhea in adults?
questions.solution:
The most common viral cause of diarrhea in adults is norovirus.

Norovirus is the most common agent to cause viral gastroenteritis among older children and adults. Noroviruses previously called Norwalk-like viruses belong to the family Caliciviridae.

Gastroenteritis caused by Norovirus has a sudden onset and generally lasts 1-3 days. It is characterized by nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, diarrhoea and constitutional symptoms like headache, fever, chills, and myalgias. Vomiting is more prevalent among children, whereas a greater proportion of adults develop diarrhoea. The stools are characteristically loose and watery, without blood, mucus, or leukocytes.

Other options:

Option A- Enteric adenoviruses cause diarrheal episodes in young children which consists of ~2–12% of all diarrheal episodes in children.

Option B- Rotavirus is the most common viral agent among young children. Nearly all children are infected with rotavirus by 3–5 years of age. Infants and young children who develop severe dehydration are more likely to have an infection from rotavirus than other viruses.

Option D- Cytomegalovirus causes mononucleosis in healthy individuals and disseminated diseases like leukopenia, hepatitis, colitis, pneumonitis, esophagitis, gastritis, and retinitis in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, he had ascites and auscultation revealed an S3.  Which of the following defects can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of bilateral pedal edema, abdominal distention, S3 heart sound are suggestive of right ventricular (RV) failure. The history of chronic smoking suggests that the patient is suffering from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)which results in cor pulmonale. Tricuspid regurgitation may be the underlying valvular defect in this patient.

The main pathophysiology behind cor pulmonale is pulmonary hypertension and increased right ventricular (RV) afterload which is sufficient to cause RV dilation with or without hypertrophy. This alters both the structure and function of the RV. In parenchymal lung diseases, primary pulmonary vascular disorders, or chronic hypoxia, the pulmonary vessels undergo vascular remodeling, vasoconstriction, and destruction leading to increased pulmonary artery pressures and increased RV afterload.

Anatomically, the right ventricle is thin-walled, compliant, and can handle volume overload better than pressure overload. Sustained pressure overload eventually leads to RV dysfunction and failure.

Dyspnea is the most common symptom. Other symptoms include pedal edema, abdominal distension due to ascites, the murmur of tricuspid regurgitation, an S3 gallop, and a palpable RV heave along the left sternal border. The jugular venous pressures (JVP) are elevated with prominent v waves indicative of tricuspid regurgitation. Other features include hepatomegaly, pulsatile liver, tenderness in the right upper quadrant, and pitting pedal edema.

The ECG in severe pulmonary hypertension shows P-pulmonale, right axis deviation, and RV hypertrophy. Spirometry and lung volumes show obstructive and/or restrictive defects seen in parenchymal lung diseases. Echo can be used to measure RV wall thickness and chamber dimensions, while doppler ECHO can be used to assess pulmonary artery pressures. Cardiac catheterization confirms the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension and can exclude elevated left-sided pressures as a cause of heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is not used to diagnose metabolic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Low-density lipoprotein is not used to diagnose metabolic syndrome.

Metabolic syndrome (syndrome X) is a group of conditions that increases the risk for cardiovascular disease.

Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III). It includes:

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively.
  • Hypertension: blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥ 85 mmHg diastolic.
  • Fasting plasma glucose level: ≥100 mg/dL or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of _____________
questions.solution:
Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy.

Primary abdominal pregnancy is the rarest type of ectopic gestation. The conceptus implants on the peritoneal surface of the abdomen.

Studdiford’s criteria:

  1. The presence of normal bilateral tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past pregnancy.
  2. No evidence of a uteroperitoneal fistula.
  3. The presence of pregnancy related exclusively to the peritoneal surface, early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. His CT scan is shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows splenic laceration. 

Splenic lacerations are linear low attenuation parenchymal defects and are almost always associated with haemoperitoneum.

The spleen is the visceral organ most commonly injured in blunt trauma abdomen. Severely ill patients may present with hypovolemic shock manifesting as tachycardia, hypotension, and pallor. A splenic rupture may not always be clinically apparent and spontaneous splenic rupture or pathological rupture can occur after minor trauma or insignificant events.

The investigation of choice in blunt trauma abdomen is CECT.

Splenic injury are currently classified into five grades based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) splenic injury scale (revised in 2018).

Management of splenic trauma:

  • Nonoperative management is preferred for stable grade I, II, or III splenic injuries.
  • Splenectomy is done for grade IV and V injuries.

CT showing splenic laceration and hematoma:

CT showing splenic rupture:

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

questions.text: A 15-year-old male undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, there is no sign of bleed. What could be the cause of this?
questions.solution:
The clinical features given in the question are suggestive of Addisonian crisis.

Addisonian crisis is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones. Normally, adrenal corticosteroids help to retain sodium and maintain normal intravascular volume. Sudden lack of these hormones causes excessive loss of sodium, decreased intravascular volume, low blood pressure and eventually circulatory collapse.

The causes are either primary or secondary. Primary causes include adrenal haemorrhage, acute infection, etc, while the secondary causes include surgery, cessation of steroid therapy, postpartum pituitary necrosis, etc.

Treatment includes fluid and glucocorticoid replacement.

questions.text: Hormone Replacement Therapy is not indicated for:
questions.solution:
Hormone Replacement Therapy is not indicated in Coronary Artery Disease prophylaxis like thromboembolism, however it is useful in certain cardiovascular disease.

Indication for HRT is as follows:

Therapeutic:

  • Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency 
  • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents

Prophylactic:

  • High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s disease and colonic cancer
  • Premature menopause following hysterectomy, tubectomy, 
  • menopause caused by radiotherapy, chemotherapy

Contraindications:

  • Breast cancer, uterine cancer or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of the thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gall bladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids—the fibroids may enlarge in size

Risks of HRT:

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Thromboembolism
  • Lipid profile dysfunction
  • Gall stones, liver dysfunction

Note:-

  • Not all women require HRT after menopause.
  • Besides, HRT does not suit all, and it may cause complications and be harmful.
  • However, it is logical to prescribe HRT and not withhold it when one needs it in the minimal effective dose for the shortest needed duration under supervision while on therapy.
  • Initially, every menopausal woman was advised to go on HRT as soon as menopause set in to be taken for several years.

Newer researches and their observations reveal that a few women need prophylactic and therapeutic HRT, but 70–85% of women remain healthy and need only good nutrition and a healthy lifestyle.

questions.text: In the following flowchart representing natural history of disease, The duration between point A to B is called as?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the first critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called lead time.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening which is the period between diagnosis by early detection and diagnosis by other means.

questions.text: A patient presented with angina. Identify the drug that can be given to this patient.
questions.solution:
Trimetazidine is an antianginal drug.

It is a PFox (partial fatty acid oxidation) inhibitor. It inhibits the beta-oxidation of fatty acids and thus enhances glucose oxidation. This results in decreased oxygen consumption in ATP synthesis as beta-oxidation consumes more oxygen.

Other options:

Option A: Thyroxine increases the heart rate, which can increase the myocardial oxygen demand and can precipitate angina.

Option B: Sumatriptan and other triptans cause coronary vasospasm. They are therefore contraindicated in patients with CAD.

Option C: Dipyridamole can produce coronary steal phenomenon and can worsen angina.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. Red cell distribution width is normal.  The peripheral smear is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and peripheral blood smear showing target cells and aniso-poikilocytosis, along with the normal red cell distribution width(RDW), are suggestive of thalassemia.

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia.

β-Thalassemia arises due to the deficient synthesis of β-chains. Normal adult RBCs have HbA, along with HbA2 and fetal haemoglobin (HbF) in small amounts. There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. 

α-Thalassemia is caused by deficient synthesis of α-chains. It can also present as an α-thalassemia trait, with trivial hematologic abnormalities. Excess of β- and γ-globin chains form Bart hemoglobin (γ4) in fetal life and HbH (β4) after birth. Severe deficiency leads to hydrops fetalis.

Ineffective erythropoiesis leads to bone marrow hyperplasia and extramedullary hematopoiesis, which can involve the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. In β-thalassemia major, anemia manifests 6 to 9 months after birth. HbF levels are markedly elevated. The presence of bony anomalies such as frontal bossing, prominent facial bones, and dental malocclusion is typical.

The image below shows thalassemic facies (frontal bossing and maxillary hyperplasia) in a child with thalassemia major. 

Laboratory findings: Infants with severe β-thalassemia diseases experience increasing anemia following the newborn stage. The RBCs exhibit microcytosis, hypochromia, and target cells. Usually observed are nucleated RBCs, a distinct anisopoikilocytosis, and relative reticulocytopenia. Without transfusions, the Hb level frequently drops to 6 g/dL in a gradual manner.

The RDW shows the size difference in the red blood cells. Low RDW means all the red blood cells are small and uniform in size, while a large RDW means that the cells vary in size. It is normal in case of thalassemia as all cells are uniformly small in size. It increases in iron deficiency anaemia because of presence of small and normal sized RBCs.

High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) confirms the diagnosis of thalassemia. It shows the absence of HbA and high levels of HbF.

Other options:

Option A: Glossitis, stomatitis, darkening of the skin on the knuckles and terminal phalanges, and enlargement of the liver and spleen are characteristics of megaloblastic anemia. Peripheral smear in megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils (shown below).

Option B: Iron deficiency anemia has high RDW. Peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia along with target cells.

Option D: Megaloblastic anemia has a particular subtype called pernicious anemia. It is caused by insufficient vitamin B12 absorption through the gastrointestinal pathway, leading to vitamin B12 insufficiency. Macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils are frequent observations in the peripheral smear associated with megaloblastic anemia. Neutrophil hypersegmentation is an early symptom of the disease and typically occurs beyond 3 to 5 lobes.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Thalassemia Minor Anemia of Chronic Disease

Serum Ferritin <30 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
Transferrin Receptor-Ferritin Index High (>2) Normal Low (<2)
MCV Decreased Markedly Decreased May be low or normal
RBC count <5 million/µL >5 million/µL Normal
Mentzer Index ≥13 <13 N/A
RDW-CV(%) >15 <15 Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: An ECG of a patient with a history of chronic kidney disease is shown below. An electrolyte abnormality is suspected and which of the following is not used in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The history of chronic kidney disease along with a sine wave pattern in ECG is suggestive of severe hyperkalemia. Beta-blockers are not used in treating this condition. On the other hand, beta-agonists can be used to correct hyperkalemia.

The most likely electrolyte abnormality that is being corrected using the above is hyperkalemia.

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium level of more than 5.5 mEq/L. It can cause drastic conduction changes. It can be diagnosed by a sequence of changes affecting the ST-T segments and QRS complex. ST-T segment changes reflect a change in repolarization, while QRS complex changes reflect a change in depolarization.

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

S. No. Serum potassium level ECG change
1 5.5–6.5 mEq/L Tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
2 6.5–7.5 mEq/L Loss of P waves
3 7.0–8.0 mEq/L Widened QRS complex
4 > 8.0 mEq/L Sine wave

Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include the following:

  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers, e.g. losartan 
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor blockers like spirinolactone, eplerenone, and drospirenone
  • Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) blockers like amiloride, triamterene, trimethoprim, pentamidine, and nafamostat

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate (Option A), which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective.
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose (Option D). The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Provide salbutamol nebulization, which will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis (Option C).

questions.text: Blood gas partition coefficient of an inhaled anesthetic is an indicator of______
questions.solution:
Blood gas partition coefficient of an inhaled anesthetic is an indicator of solubility in the blood which determines the speed of induction and recovery.

An inhalational anesthetic with lower blood gas partition coefficient would have lower solubility in blood. This would mean a higher alveolar concentration which will lead to faster induction and recovery.

Xenon with a blood-gas partition coefficient of 0.115 has the fastest induction and emergence from anesthesia. Methoxyflurane with a blood gas partition coefficient of 12 has the slowest induction and emergence from anesthesia.

The speed of induction and emergence: Xenon>Desflurane>Sevoflurane>Isoflurane>Enflurane>Halothane>Methoxyflurane

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presented with multiple soft tissue hemangiomas in the upper limbs and the radiograph of the patient is shown below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows multiple tumors affecting the bones of the hand with soft tissue swellings and calcification which is suggestive of enchondromatosis.

Enchondromatosis with hemangioma of the overlying soft tissue constitutes Maffucci’s syndrome.

Multiple enchondromas when present without hemangiomas is called as Ollier disease.

Malignant potential:

  • Maffuccci’s syndrome has 100% risk of turning into malignancy.
  • Ollier disease has a risk of 30% to turn into malignancy.
  • Solitary enchondroma has <2% risk of conversion to chondrosarcoma.

Note: Most common tumor in bones of hand -Enchondroma.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image below:
questions.solution: The image given is of Morris Retractor, which is a big retractor useful for giving maximum exposure in large incisions such as those used in the abdomen. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision (by pulling firmly in that direction); so is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old healthy male presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. During the physical examination, the physician palpates a pulsatile abdominal mass and orders an abdominal ultrasound. The ultrasound reveals an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient asks the physician about the threshold diameter above which surgical repair is recommended. What is the correct answer?
questions.solution:
Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm >5.5 cm should undergo operative repair.

Indications for operative repair in abdominal aortic:

  • Abdominal aortic aneurysm of any size:
    • Which is expanding rapidly
    • Associated with symptoms
  • Asymptomatic >5.5 cm

Indications for operative repair in thoracic aortic:

Clinical scenario Indication for operative repair
Symptomatic aneurysm Any size
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter > 5.5 cm
When the diameter of an ascending aortic aneurysm has increased > 0.5 cm per year
Asymptomatic descending thoracic aortic diameter or > 6 cm
When the diameter of descending  aortic aneurysm has increased  > 1 cm per year
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter in patients with Marfan’s syndrome or bicuspid aortic valve 4-5cm

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and palpitations. Her ECG strip is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Narrow complex tachycardia without visible P waves and sudden onset palpitations as shown in the ECG suggests AV node reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). It is a type of Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

The given ECG strip shows changes suggestive of AV node reentry tachycardia based on the following findings-

  • Narrow QRS complex tachycardia at 150 bpm (green arrows) - indicative of a regular atrial rate (1:1 AV response). Heart rate is calculated by dividing 300 by the number of large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves. The ECG strip shows the presence of roughly 2 large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves, thereby making the HR ~150 bpm.
  • No visible P waves - indicative of dual conduction pathways (slow and fast) that cause simultaneous atrial and ventricular activation.
  • The P wave may sometimes be seen at the end of the QRS complex as a pseudo-r' wave (V1) (black arrow) and pseudo-S wave (II, III, aVF) (blue arrows). 

Carotid sinus massage (or any other vagal manoeuvre) will be the best next step in management as vagal manoeuvres can terminate approximately 10-20% of AVNRT.

Other options:

Option B: Atrial fibrillation (ECG given below)Rhythm is irregularly irregular. P waves are absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Option C: Atrial flutter (ECG given below)Rhythm is regular. The rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw tooth-shaped waves known as flutter waves.

Option D: Sinus tachycardia (ECG given below) Normal sinus mechanism precipitated by exertion, stress, concurrent illness

questions.text: Chadwick sign is seen in _____
questions.solution:
Jacquemier’s or Chadwick’s sign is the dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall visible at around 8th week of pregnancy. The discolouration is due to local vascular congestion.

During pregnancy, there is increased vascularity and hyperemia in the skin and muscles of the perineum and vulva. This increased vascularity prominently affects the vagina and cervix and results in the bluish tint of the vagina and ectocervix which is characteristic of the Chadwick sign.

questions.text: According to WHO, which of the following are components of the Human Development Index (HDI)?

choices.text: Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living
Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.solution:
The components of the Human Development Index (HDI) include life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living.

Human Development Index (HDI) is a measure of a country's average achievements in three dimensions of human development:

  • A long and healthy life, as measured by life expectancy at birth
  • Knowledge (literacy), as measured by mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling, and
  • A decent standard of living, as measured by GNI (gross national income) per capita.

HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value.

Note- Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate are components of the Physical quality of life index (PQLI).

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioral change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The triad of dementia, ataxic or apractic gait and urinary incontinence is seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus.

The triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (Adam’s/Hakim’s triad):

  • Dementia
  • Ataxia (gait disturbance) or apractic
  • Urinary incontinence

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (Hakim-Adams syndrome):

  • It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.
  • Caused by conditions producing scarring of basilar meninges
  • Communicating hydrocephalus is seen
  • A reversible cause of dementia
  • Adam’s / Hakim’s triad (as mentioned above)
  • Papilloedema is not seen.
  • Dilated lateral ventricles with little or no cortical atrophy are seen on neuroimaging and the lumbar puncture opening pressure is in the high-normal range.
  • Treatment - Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting
  • CSF parameters are normal usually

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

CONDITION FEATURES
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus &/or seizures

questions.text: During a code blue situation, healthcare providers are actively resuscitating a patient in cardiac arrest according to Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS) guidelines. The team leader asks about the components of ACLS interventions. Which among the following is not included in the ACLS guidelines?
questions.solution:
Sodium bicarbonate injection is not a part of ACLS guidelines.

Drugs used in ACLS are 

  • Epinephrine
  • Amiodarone
  • Lignocaine
  • Beta-blockers

Magnesum sulphate may be used in Torsades de pointes and in hypomagnesemia

questions.text: A 26-year-old actor came with complaints of being unable to focus on his work. He worked for a short while in various occupations, before deciding he wanted to be an actor. After attending several auditions, he discovered that he was easily distracted, needed help remembering his lines, and even drifted off during reading. Identify the disorder in the given scenario.
questions.solution:
The disorder in the given scenario can be identified as Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuropsychiatric condition affecting children, adolescents, and adults around the world, characterized by a pattern of diminished sustained attention, and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. They often have significant impairment in academic functioning as well as in social and interpersonal situations.

ADHD was historically believed to be a childhood condition resulting in delayed development of impulse control that would be generally outgrown by adolescence. Over the past few decades, a significant number of adults with ADHD have been found, diagnosed, and given effective treatment. Utah Criteria for Adult Attention-Deficit/ Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) include retrospective diagnosis of ADHD in childhood and evidence of current impairment from ADHD symptoms in adulthood. 

Adults with residual illness exhibit impulsivity and attention deficit symptoms, such as trouble focusing, difficulty organizing and finishing tasks, increased distractibility, and making snap decisions without considering the repercussions. Many individuals with the illness also suffer from a secondary depressive disorder, which is linked to low self-esteem as a result of their diminished performance, which has an impact on social and professional functioning.

A variety of medications and behavioural interventions are used to treat ADHD. The most widely used medications are methylphenidate and atomoxetine. A combination of medication and psychotherapy is more effective than either treatment alone.

Other options: 

Option A: Patients with chronic depression will usually have low mood and loss of interest in general and this does not fit into the given scenario.

Option B: Borderline personality disorder is characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behaviour, object relations, and self-image. Instability in affect due to a marked reactivity of mood. It is characterized by repeated suicidal behaviour, unstable interpersonal relationships, prolonged feelings of emptiness, inappropriate, intense anger, or difficulty in controlling anger. 

Option C: Manic disorder is usually seen with grandiosity and other psychotic symptoms that do not fit into the given situation.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male patient presented with painless, fleshy, exophytic lesions on the surface of the penis. Evaluation reveals the causative organism to be low-risk strains of HPV. What is the first-line management used for this condition?

HPV - human papillomavirus
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of painless exophytic lesions on the genitalia caused by low-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) strains is suggestive of anogenital warts. Imiquimod is the first-line drug used in the management of this condition.

Anogenital warts are caused by low-risk strains of HPV, commonly HPV-6 and HPV-11. The lesions present as soft, pink, and fleshy warts. These growths may be pedunculated or verrucous and coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths known as condyloma acuminata.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by HPV DNA PCR (polymerase chain reaction). 

The image below shows anogenital warts on the penis:


The first-line drugs used in the treatment are topical podophyllin and imiquimod. Second-line management includes cryotherapy, local application of fluorouracil, or 80–90% trichloroacetic acid. Cryotherapy is a relatively safer management that can be used in pregnant women for treating warts.

questions.text: The given clinical finding can be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a red tongue with prominent papillae is suggestive of a strawberry red tongue which is seen in Kawasaki's disease.

Kawasaki's disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome. It is a vasculitis condition of unknown etiology.  Clinical features include a high spiking fever that is unresponsive to antipyretics. The fever can last between 5 days to 3-4 weeks. The five principal clinical criteria for Kawasaki's disease are: 

  • Bilateral nonexudative conjunctival injection with limbal sparing
  • Erythema of the oral and pharyngeal mucosa, strawberry tongue, and red, cracked lips
  • Edema and erythema of the hands and feet
  • Various forms of rash- maculopapular, erythema multiforme, scarlatiniform
  • Nonsuppurative cervical lymphadenopathy

Diagnosis requires fever and at least four of the five principal criteria. Myocarditis develops frequently in acute Kawasaki disease. It presents as tachycardia and reduced ventricular systolic function. The tachycardia will be disproportionate to the fever. Patients may develop coronary artery aneurysms in the 2nd to 3rd week of illness. They are generally asymptomatic and diagnosed on echocardiography. However, if large it can lead to death. Thus, echocardiography should be performed at diagnosis and after 1-2 weeks. 

Other options:

Options A and C: Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency are associated with a beefy red sore tongue. It can be differentiated from the strawberry red tongue by the absence of hypertrophied papillae.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is associated with strawberry gingiva which involves hypertrophied gums with petechial hemorrhages giving a strawberry appearance. 

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival injection (90% of cases)

questions.text: A 20-year-old lady presents with sudden palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, and a feeling like she is being choked. She had a history of a COVID-19 infection 1 year ago and fears she might die because she was positive for COVID-19. Physical examination, ECG, and laboratory workup were unremarkable. This is the first time she is experiencing an episode like this which lasts normally for around 20 minutes. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a classic panic attack as she has symptoms of palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, feelings of choking and fear of dying although her examination and lab findings are normal. 

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort that may last from minutes to hours. Recurrent panic attacks are termed panic disorders.

Panic attacks can occur in other disorders, particu­larly in specific phobias, social phobias, and post-traumatic stress disorder. 

Unexpected panic attacks occur at any time and are not associated with any identifiable situational trigger. Attacks in patients with social and specific pho­bias are usually expected in response to a specific stimulus.

Some panic attacks do not fit into unexpected or expected attacks, and these attacks are referred to as situationally predisposed panic attacks. They may or may not occur on exposure to a specific trigger, or may occur immediately after exposure or after a considerable period of time.

Four or more of the following should be present to label it a panic attack:

  • Palpitations, pounding heart, or accelerated heart rate.
  • Sweating.
  • Trembling or shaking
  • Sensations of shortness of breath or smothering
  • Feelings of choking
  • Chest pain or discomfort.
  • Nausea or abdominal distress.
  • Dizziness, unsteady, light-headed, or faint
  • Chills or heat sensations
  • Paresthesias
  • Derealization (feelings of unreality) or depersonalization (feeling detached from oneself)
  • Fear of losing control or "going crazy."
  • Fear of dying

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.
Occur spontaneously without overt precipitants.
 
They often avoid situations/ places in which panic attacks have occurred.

Treatment is with benzodiazepines or SSRI/ SNRI and cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific to social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: What does the below diagram indicate?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the placental villi penetrating through the myometrium and getting attached to the serosa. Hence, this is known as placenta percreta.

Placenta Accrete syndromes include any placental implantation with abnormally firm adherence to myometrium because of the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid Nitabuch layer. 

Variants of placenta accreta syndromes are classified by the depth of trophoblastic growth:

Types

Definition

Placenta accreta  

Villi are attached to the myometrium.

Placenta increta 

Villi invade the myometrium. 

Placenta percreta 

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa. 


MR imaging can be used as an adjunct to sonography to define anatomy, degree of invasion, and possible ureteral or bladder involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hyper-estrogenic condition?
questions.solution:
Low body mass index (BMI) is not a hyper-estrogenic condition. In fact, low BMI can lead to decreased estrogen levels, as body fat plays a role in estrogen production.

Hyper-estrogenic conditions refer to conditions where there is an excessive level of estrogen in the body.

Estrogen is a hormone that plays a key role in the development of female sexual characteristics and the regulation of the menstrual cycle. 

Other options:

  • Some specific subtypes of ovarian tumors, such as Granulosa Cell Tumors and Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumors, can produce excess estrogen, leading to hyper-estrogenic effects. However, the majority of ovarian cancers are not typically associated with hyper-estrogenic conditions.
  • Tamoxifen is a medication often used in the treatment of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. It acts as a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), blocking estrogen receptors. It acts as an estrogen antagonist in the breast and an estrogen agonist in the endometrium.
  • Endometriosis involves the growth of tissue similar to the lining of the uterus (endometrium) outside the uterus. It's often associated with estrogen, as estrogen can stimulate the growth of endometrial tissue.

questions.text: Triad of Gregg in a fetus is seen in congenital infection with ____
questions.solution:
Triad of Gregg is seen in a neonate infected congenitally with Rubella virus. The features include:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus(PDA)
  • Cataract
  • Sensorineural Hearing loss(SNHL)

Other infections which cause congenital malformations are:

Organism Effect
Toxoplasma

Hydro/Microcephaly,Convulsions,

Chorioretinitis, Cerebral calcification
Rubella PDA, Cataract, SNHL
Varicella

Skin scarring, Hypoplastic limbs,

Eye defects, Microcephaly
Parvovirus Non immune hydrops
Syphyllis

Bone defect hydrops

questions.text: Which of the following is not an AIDS-defining illness?
questions.solution:
Out of the given conditions, primary brain lymphoma, toxoplasmosis of the brain, and wasting syndrome are considered AIDS-defining illnesses. 

While candidiasis of the respiratory tract (trachea, bronchi, and lungs) and oesophagus is considered to be an AIDS-defining illness, oral candidiasis (oral thrush) is not AIDS-defining.

Generalized wasting is also an AIDS-defining condition. It is defined as involuntary weight loss of >10% of body weight with fever and chronic diarrhoea lasting >30 days without any other cause. Severe muscle wasting with myofiber degeneration is seen in this condition. The most severe form of neurocognitive disorder associated with HIV, HIV-associated dementia, is also considered to be an AIDS-defining condition.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl who was diagnosed with SLE at 13 years of age is now refractory to standard treatment. She is prescribed a monoclonal antibody which is an anti-B-cell activator. Which of the following drugs is she prescribed?
questions.solution:
Belimumab is a monoclonal antibody that is an anti-B-cell activator. It is used in the management of lupus refractory to standard treatment. 

Belimumab inhibits the soluble form of a B cell survival factor (known as BLyS or BAFF) which promotes the formation of memory B cells and autoantibodies. It is used in combination with either cyclophosphamide or MMF in patients with lupus nephritis who do not show a response to initial therapy with steroids.

Other options:

Option A: Rozanolixizumab is a humanized IgG4 monoclonal antibody that has been recently FDA-approved for the treatment of myasthenia gravis.

Option C: Daclizumab is an IL2R antagonist that binds to CD25 and is used in the relapsing type of multiple sclerosis.

Option D: Adalimumab is an anti-TNF alpha agent used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of skin lesions that have recently appeared on his arms and trunk.  The clinical appearance is given below. Which of the following conditions is characteristically associated with these skin lesions?
questions.solution:
• This is an image of a typical target lesion. It is also called as iris lesion or bull's eye lesion.
  • Target lesions are characteristically seen in Erythema multiforme. 
  • They have 3 or more zones.
    • Central area of dusky erythema or purpura
    • Middle paler zone of edema
    • Outer ring of erythema with a well defined edge
  • Atypical target lesions with only 2 zones may be seen in in Stevens-Johnson Syndrome and Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with chronic kidney disease comes for a routine follow-up. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a mitral annular calcification. It is a chronic degenerative process affecting the mitral valve ring and can be a rheumatic sequela. 

The clinical vignette gives clues towards the multiple co-morbidities and complications that may be associated with MAC. 

  • Stroke
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Chronic Kidney Disease 
  • Mitral Regurgitation 
  • Mitral Stenosis 
  • Arrhythmias, atrial fibrillation 
  • Endocarditis 
  • Aortic Stenosis 

Surgical treatment is indicated only if concomitant stenosis or regurgitation is to be corrected. Severe MAC makes the surgery difficult. Isolated MAC does not require endocarditis prophylaxis. Anti-coagulation and anti-platelet medications are recommended within the guidelines of treatment of the comorbid conditions. 

Other options:

In aortic sclerosis, there can be aortic valvular calcifications with cardiomegaly. Signs of heart failure such as pulmonary venous congestion and pulmonary interstitial/alveolar edema can be seen. 

Atrial Myxomas have non-specific x-ray findings- 

  • Cardiomegaly: left atrial enlargement
  • Intracardiac tumoral calcification
  • Mitral valve obstruction evidence 
  • Elevated left atrial pressure findings- pulmonary edema

A calcified atrial thrombus is a rare entity that may show up as calcified lesions in the cardiac shadow on a chest x-ray. They are usually discovered by transthoracic echocardiography.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image below
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the given image is a pair of episiotomy scissors.

Episiotomy is a surgically planned incision on the perineum and posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. It is commonly done to enlarge the vaginal introitus to facilitate the safe delivery of the fetus.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with AV block?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is associated with AV block.

Causes of AV block:

Autonomic:

  • Carotid sinus hypersensitivity

Metabolic:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypermagnesemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Adrenal insufficiency

Drug related:

  • Beta blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers
  • Adenosine
  • Digitalis
  • Lithium
  • Class 1 and class 3 anti arrhythmics

Infections:

  • Endocarditis
  • Lyme disease
  • Chaga's disease
  • Syphilis
  • Tuberculosis
  • Diphtheria
  • Toxoplasmosis

Inflammatory:

  • SLE
  • RA
  • Scleroderma

Infiltrative:

  • Amyloidosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hemachromatosis

questions.text: You are posted in your medicine ward and your consultant asks you to prescribe an ultra-short-acting insulin to a patient. Inside the drug tray, you notice the following drugs. Identify the drug that you will not give to the patient.
questions.solution:
Glargine is a long-acting insulin. Hence, it will not be given to the patient in this scenario.

Aspart, Lispro and Glulisine are all ultra-short-acting insulins.

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

Ultra short acting:

  • Aspart
  • Glulisine
  • Lispro

Short acting:

  • Regular

Intermediate acting:

  • NPH
  • Lente

Long acting:

  • Detemir
  • Glargine
  • Degludec

questions.text: What is the single most important galactopoetic hormone in post-natal women?
questions.solution:
Prolactin is the single most important galactopoietic hormone in postnatal women.

Function Definition Hormone
Mammogenesis Breast growth and development

Estrogen (ductal growth)

Progesterone (alveolar growth)

questions.text: Which among the following images of pressure sores has the highest risk of developing osteomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Image 3 shows complete skin loss that involves muscles and shows exposed bone indicating a Category 4 pressure sore and has the highest risk of developing osteomyelitis.

Pressure sores are skin or soft tissue injuries that occur due to prolonged pressure over specific areas of the body. An external pressure of >30 mmHg leads to the formation of pressure sores. The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are the ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral followed by medial), and occiput.

The grading system for the description of pressure sores:

Category 1 - Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
Category 2 - Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
Category 3 - Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
Category 4 - Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon, or joint.

Below is the image showing the stages of pressure sore.

Management:

Pressure sores can be prevented with good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special pressure-dispersion cushions, or foams. Repositioning the patient every two hours can lessen the pressure on the area. 

Ulcers of stages I and II often do not require operative measures. The main aim of treatment for pressure ulcers is:

  • To reduce the pressure exerted on the ulcer.
  • Decrease moisture.
  • To keep it as aseptic or least septic as possible.

The ulcer should be cleaned and drained to remove any dead tissue and debris. Good antibiotic cover and hydrocolloid dressing are useful.

Stage 3 and 4 ulcers may require surgical intervention. Surgical management of pressure sores follows the same principles involved in acute wound treatment. Prior to the operation, the pressure sores should be adequately debrided, and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) can be used to promote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction.

The following is an image showing VAC:

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the clinic because she is feeling excessively tired these days. She is unable to carry out her day-to-day household works. She says that for the past few months she is having excessive and very frequent menstrual bleeding. On examination, she appears pale, with a smooth tongue. Peripheral smear shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most reliable test to assess the iron stores in her body?
questions.solution:
The patient has features of iron deficiency anemia due to excessive menstrual bleeding. Serum ferritin is the most reliable test to assess the iron stores in her body.

The majority of the patients with iron deficiency anemia present with easy fatigability, tachycardia, palpitations, and dyspnea on exertion. Severe deficiency causes skin and mucosal changes like

  • smooth tongue
  • brittle nails
  • koilonychia- spooning of nails
  • cheilosis- fissures at the corner of the mouth
  • pica- craving for specific foods that are not rich in iron.

Laboratory investigation of iron deficiency anemia

The peripheral smear will show small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic) cells with an increased area of central pallor. Pencil-shaped cells can be seen which is called poikilocytosis.

Serum iron levels- It represents the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. The normal range for the serum iron is 50–150 μg/dL. It is decreased in iron deficiency anemia.

Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC)- It is an indirect measure of the circulating transferrin. The normal levels are 300–360 μg/dL. The levels are increased in IDA.

Transferrin saturation- The normal levels are 25–50%. The levels are decreased in IDA.

Serum ferritin- Free iron is toxic to the body. Therefore it is bound to a protein called apoferritin to form ferritin. Adult males have serum ferritin values averaging 100 μg/L, while adult females have levels averaging 30 μg/L. The serum ferritin level is the most convenient laboratory test to estimate iron stores. It is decreased in IDA.

Evaluation of bone marrow iron stores- can be done by performing bone marrow biopsy and using the Prussian stain to stain the iron stores. It is rarely done these days due to the availability of the serum ferritin estimation tests.

questions.text: What is the negatively charged anode target made up of in conventional x-ray tube?
questions.solution:
The negatively charged anode target is made up of tungsten + rhenium in a conventional X-ray tube.

Tungsten 90% + rhenium 10% alloy helps in better dissipation of heat generated on striking electrons to the target anode.

Other options:

Option A: Tungsten + thorium alloy is used as the cathode filament which is the positive terminal of the x-ray tube.

Option C: Molybdenum is used as the anode material in mammography tubes.

Option D: Lead is used for the outer housing of the x-ray tube.

questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress and drooling of saliva. Nasogastric tube cannot be passed to the stomach. There is history of maternal polyhydramnios. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of esophageal atresia with or without TEF.  In the setting of early-onset respiratory distress, the inability to pass a nasogastric or orogastric tube in the newborn suggests EA.

Features:

  • Esophageal atresia (EA) is the most common congenital anomaly of the esophagus. It is often associated with single umbilical artery.
  • >90% of babies with EA have an associated tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).
  • In the most common form of EA, the upper esophagus ends in a blind pouch and the TEF is connected to the distal esophagus.

CXR of pure EA can manifest as an airless scaphoid abdomen.

CXR showing a coiled feeding tube in the esophageal pouch and an air-distended stomach, indicating the presence of a coexisting TEF.

Other options:

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia:

Presents with respiratory distress in the neonatal period, scaphoid abdomen and bowel sounds which are present in the chest wall.
The tip of NG tube will be in the stomach in the thoracic cavity.
CXR shows: shows a stomach, nasogastric tube, and small bowel contents in the thoracic cavity, consistent with a CDH.

Acute Gastric Volvulus presents with classic symptoms (Borchardt triad) which include:

  • Unproductive retching (here patient presents with drooling NOT retching)
  • Localised epigastric distension
  • Inability to pass NG tube

questions.text: A 28-year-old multiparous woman delivered a full-term male baby by spontaneous vaginal delivery. Soon after the baby's delivery, the patient immediately went into a state of shock. Even after starting IV fluids, the shock seems to be out of proportion to the degree of bleeding. On abdominal examination, the fundus of the uterus could not be felt and per vaginal examination revealed no obvious source of bleeding. What is the most probable diagnosis among the following options?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of shock immediately after delivery and absent uterine fundus on abdominal examination is suggestive of uterine inversion. 

Uterine inversion is a rare cause of postpartum collapse which is acute in onset and occurs immediately after delivery.

Causes:

  • Mismanagement of 3rd stage of labor - Delivering a yet to be separated placenta (Creede’s method)
  • Spontaneous
  • Placenta accreta.

Features:

  • Shock appears immediately after delivery.
  • The degree of shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding
  • Shock is both neurogenic and hemorrhagic.
  • Per abdomen examination: Fundus of the uterus is felt to be absent. 

Management:

The following steps are done in uterine inversion.

  • Discontinue uterotonics
  • Administration of IV crystalloids through large-bore IV cannulas to prevent/treat neurogenic and hemorrhagic shock. This is followed by blood transfusion to replace losses.
  • Repositioning is tried after confirming that the inverted uterus is not firmly retracted or contracted. If the placenta is attached to the uterus, it is done with the placenta in-situ. The palm and the fingers are used to push up the uterine fundus along the vaginal axis.
  • Administer tocolytics such as terbutaline, magnesium sulphate, and nitroglycerin can be used to relax the uterus for repositioning, if the initial attempt has failed. An inhalational anaesthetic agent can be used if relaxation is not sufficient with tocolytics. Once the uterus is relaxed, repositioning is re-attempted.
  • Oxytocin infusion is started and tocolytics are stopped after repositioning. Await spontaneous expulsion of placenta.
  • The position of the uterus is maintained while applying bimanual compression.
  • Surgical intervention is needed if repositioning fails or can't be done.

questions.text: A 38-year-old professor with depression requests you to prescribe an antidepressant that would be least likely to cause sexual dysfunction. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Bupropion can be prescribed as it decreases the chance of causing sexual dysfunction.

  • It enhances both noradrenergic and dopaminergic neurotransmission by inhibiting reuptake.
  • Used for aiding smoking cessation and for the treatment of depression in combination with SSRIs.
  • Adverse effects of bupropion include stimulant side effects like tachycardia, insomnia, headache, and seizures in anorexic/bulimic patients. 
  • It decreases the risk of sexual dysfunction and weight gain compared to other antidepressants.

Venlafaxine is a serotonin noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor used in the treatment of major depression, generalized anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. Adverse effects are nausea, sexual dysfunction, and sustained elevation of blood pressure.

Escitalopram and fluoxetine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors used in the treatment of major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia and anorexia nervosa, and generalized anxiety disorders. Adverse effects are dry mouth, urinary retention, and sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: A person had an accidental spillover of hot liquid. On examination, there were multiple fluid-filled blisters, which when ruptured have an erythematous base. They are extremely painful and blanch to touch. Which layer is involved in blister formation in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of superficial partial-thickness burns. The papillary dermis is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial thickness burn.

  • First degree: Involves only epidermis, with pain and redness
  • Second degree: Involves epidermis and some part of dermis (also known as partial thickness burns). Further divided into:
    • Superficial second degree or superficial partial thickness involves upper part of dermis (papillary) - pain, blisters, severe swelling.
    • Deep second degree or deep partial thickness - extends up to reticular layer of dermis; appear more pale and mottled, do not blanch to touch, but remain painful to pinprick.
  • Third degree or full thickness burns - involves full thickness of dermis and subcutaneous tissue.
  • Fourth degree burns - involves deep structures such as muscle, bone and brain.

questions.text:
You are a medical officer on camp duty seeing patients who have come for the removal of contraceptive devices. You notice the following contraceptive devices being used. Which of the following is incorrect about these devices?

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease - PID

choices.text: Can be used as an emergency contraceptive
Can be used in patients with mennorrhagia
Functions by causing an inflammatory response within the uterus

questions.solution:
The image shows types of Copper T. The statement that it 'can be used in patients with menorrhagia' is incorrect about the copper T. Copper T's are contraindicated in patients with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and anemia as it can worsen the condition. 

Copper T is a type of intrauterine contraception device (IUCD). They provide long-term, reversible method of contraception.

Types:

  • Medicated IUCD's such as progestasert, levonova, and mirena which release hormones for contraception.
  • Unmedicated IUCD's such as the copper T, in order to induce contraception. 

The copper T functions by causing an inflammatory response (Option D) within the uterus which leads to spermicide. The same response also makes it difficult for blastocyst implantation. 

IUCDs can be placed in women who have a low risk of sexually transmitted diseases, are multiparous, monogamous, and want long-term contraception without permanent sterilization. These have the advantage of not having to take a daily oral contraceptive pill. 

The copper T can also be used as emergency contraception (Option A) and left inside the uterus long term for contraception. 

It is contraindicated in the following situations: 

  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Fibroid uterus (Option C) as there will be structural issues
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease or lower genital tract infections
  • Menorrhagia or dysmenorrhea
  • Anemia
  • Uncontrolled diabetes due to increased risk of infection
  • Previous ectopic pregnancy 
  • Scarred uterus
  • Abnormally shaped uterus

In addition, hormonal IUCDs should not be given in women with history of breast cancer. 

The following image shows the Nova T. It has silver in addition to the copper wire which makes its lifespan 5 years. 

The copper T 380A is also known as Paraguard. It has a lifespan of 10 years. It has 380 mm2 surface area spread out across the stem and the sleeves. 

The multiload 375 has 375 mm2 of copper wire wrapped around the stem. It has to be replaced every 5 years. It does not have an introducer or plunger. 

The copper T 200 has 215mm2 of copper around the stem. It has a polyethylene frame with monofilaments attached to the end of the stem. The threads are used for removal. Barium sulfate is added to the stem to increase radioopacity when performing xrays. It has a lifespan of 3 years. 

The following images represent the copper T 380A, multiload 375, and copper T 200. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week
