questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation, and on examination slow ankle jerk with a TSH level of 15 IU/L and low T3, and T4. Of the following, the next best step in the management of this patient is to:

choices.text: Order a thyroid radionuclide uptake and scan

questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is hypothyroidism. Thyroid hormone replacement with levothyroxine should be started immediately after diagnosis.

Laboratory investigations in a patient with hypothyroidism would show low levels of total and free T3, T4, and rT3, with high TSH levels and normal combined protein levels.

Normally, the thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) is released by the hypothalamus. It stimulates the pituitary gland to release the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which in turn stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4 hormones. Elevated TSH with a low level of free T4 is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism.

In the case of secondary hypothyroidism, TSH levels may be low, normal, or even slightly increased. The latter is due to the secretion of immunoactive but bio-inactive forms of TSH. The diagnosis is confirmed by the detection of a low unbound T4 level. 

Patients with hypothyroidism often present with tiredness, weakness, dry skin, hair loss, difficulty concentrating, poor memory, constipation, cold intolerance, and weight gain with poor appetite. On examination, they may have cool peripheral extremities, puffy faces, hyporeflexia, bradycardia, and peripheral edema.

The best outcomes occur when levothyroxine therapy is started immediately after diagnosis. The clinical effects of levothyroxine replacement are slow to appear. 

If there is no residual function, the daily replacement dose of levothyroxine is usually 1.6 μg/kg body weight (typically 100–150 μg), ideally taken at least 30 minutes before breakfast.

TSH responses are gradual and should be determined 2 months following the initiation of treatment or change in dose. Once the full replacement is achieved and TSH levels are stable, TSH measurement is recommended at annual intervals.

In patients who have developed hypothyroidism following treatment of Graves' disease, lower doses are needed for replacement. This is because there is often underlying autonomous function, necessitating lower replacement doses (typically 75–125 μg/d).

Related Pearl: Causes of hypothyroidism:

 

Primary (Low T3, T4 > Raised TSH levels) Secondary (Low TSH levels > Low T3, T4) Tertiary ( Low TRH > Low TSH > Low T3,T4 )

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Excessive iodine intake - Wolff Chiakoff effect

Subacute thyrioditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Iodine deficiency, dyshormonogenesis

Pituitary tumour

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

Resistance to thyroid hormone

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida with twin gestation presents to the clinic in active labor. The first baby is in breech presentation and the second baby is in cephalic presentation. What is the best step of management in this condition?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, since the first twin is in breech (non-cephalic presentation), the best step of management is to deliver through cesarean section.

Scheme of management of twins in labor:

  1. If the first twin/ both twins are in the non-cephalic presentation: deliver through cesarean section.
  2. If the first twin is in vertex presentation: Deliver the first twin through vaginal delivery and do not give methergine post-delivery of the first baby. Delivering the second twin, If it is in,
  • Breech: Deliver through breech extraction
  • Transverse lie
    • If the obstetrician is skilled in podalic version: Internal podalic version and breech extraction under GA. 
    • If the obstetrician is unskilled: External version into a longitudinal lie preferably cephalic or if that fails podalic. 
  • Vertex: Vaginal delivery, assisted forceps/ventouse.

Cesarean delivery of the breech fetus is indicated in the following:

  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech
  • Large fetus: >3800 to 4000 g
  • Apparently healthy and viable preterm fetus either with active labor or with indicated delivery
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech

questions.text: A pregnant woman complained of excessive vomiting and mild vaginal bleeding for 2 weeks at a period of gestation of 14 weeks. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 16 weeks and fetal heart sound is absent.  USG shows the presence of a snowstorm appearance. What is the management____
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy and regardless of uterine size, molar evacuation by suction and curettage is usually the preferred treatment. 

With large moles, adequate anesthesia, sufficient intravenous access, and blood-banking support are imperative.

Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied.

Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their family.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN.

questions.text: When is dilatation and curettage contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) as it increases the risk of ascending genital infection.

D&C is a minor gynecological procedure of dilating the cervix and curetting the endometrial tissue from the uterine cavity. Diagnostic indications of D&C include AUB, secondary amenorrhea to detect tubercular endometritis, postmenopausal bleeding to rule out endometrial cancer or hyperplasia, and infertility due to genital TB.

Therapeutic indications of D&C include missed abortion, incomplete abortion, retained products of conception, and endometrial polypectomy.

Absolute contraindication of D&C includes Suspected/ desired pregnancy and lower genital tract infection. However, D&C is performed in some cases with genital infections like septic abortion (where retained pieces of placenta act as a nidus and need to be removed) and pyometra (as there is cervical obstruction with superinfection of menstrual blood and cellular debris, D&C is appropriate to remove the obstruction as well as the source of infection)

Complications of D&C include ascending infection, cervical tear with bleeding, incompetent os, uterine perforation, and Ashermann syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty ward with a high fever and pain abdomen for 2 days.  He has had bloody diarrhea for the past several months. The abdominal radiograph of this patient is given below. What is the condition seen in the image?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon. Abdominal radiography in toxic megacolon shows transverse or right colonic dilation more than 6 cms. Loss of haustrations is also seen. 

Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension or features of sepsis. It is seen in severe ulcerative colitis.

questions.text:
Match the following:
1. Mondor's disease a. Recurrent periductal mastitis
2. Tietze’s syndrome b. Lymphangiosarcoma 
3. Zuska’s disease c. Thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of the breast
4. Stewart-Treves syndrome  d. Benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages
questions.solution:
The correctly matched options are as follows:

1. Mondor's disease c. Thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of the breast
2. Tietze’s syndrome d. Benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages
3. Zuska’s disease a. Recurrent periductal mastitis
4. Stewart-Treves syndrome  b. Lymphangiosarcoma 

 

Option 1: Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. It may also occur in the arm or penis. On raising the arm, the skin over the chest gets stretched and a narrow, shallow groove alongside the cord is seen. Symptomatic management & reassurance are best suited for it, as it typically resolves in a few weeks. The differential diagnosis to be considered is lymphatic permeation from occult breast carcinoma.

The image below shows a thrombosed subcutaneous cord attached to the skin pathognomic of Mondor's disease.

Option 2: Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition. It is managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage if necessary.

Option 3: Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphoedema following mastectomy. This syndrome is observed in the setting of chronic lymphedema after axillary dissection for breast cancer. It develops on an extremity ipsilateral to an axillary lymphadenectomy. It appears on the upper, medial arm as a violaceous plaque with nonpitting edema and has poor survival. Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice but the rate of recurrence is high.

Option 4: Benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages is referred to as Tietze’s syndrome. Tietze syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages and an extra-mammary cause of chest wall pain. This commonly presents in postmenopausal women who are not taking HRT, as non-cyclical mastalgia, and the pain often radiates to the neck and shoulders. Treatment can be done with non-steroidal analgesics or by injection with a local anaesthetic on a ‘trigger spot’.

questions.text: A study conducted in a group revealed that consumption of alcohol increases the risk of esophageal cancer, but it may be actually due to cigarette smoking. This happens due to:
questions.solution:
In this scenario, cigarette smoking is related to both the outcome of esophageal cancer and consumption of alcohol. Thus, this is an example of a confounding factor.

A confounding factor is defined as one which is associated with both exposure and outcome and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. In this study to determine the role of alcohol in the etiology of esophageal cancer, smoking is considered as a confounding factor because:

  • It is associated with the consumption of alcohol (exposure).
  • It is an independent risk factor for oesophageal cancer (outcome).

In these conditions, the effects of alcohol consumption can be determined only if the influence of smoking is neutralized by matching.

questions.text: Which of the following ligaments is most likely injured after a dashboard injury?
questions.solution:
Following a dashboard injury the most likely ligament to have injured is the posterior cruciate ligament. 

During a dashboard injury, the strong force on the anterior aspect of the tibia causes posterior translation of the tibia with respect to the femur, which results in posterior cruciate ligament injury.

The patient usually presents with a swollen and tender knee with hemarthrosis. The posterior drawer test to identify the posterior cruciate ligament tear is difficult to perform because of the pain and swelling. X-ray of the knee shows effusion. The posterior cruciate ligament injury can be definitively diagnosed with MRI as shown below.

Dashboard injury can lead to 

  • Posterior hip dislocation
  • Patellar fracture
  • Fracture neck of femur
  • Acetabular fracture
  • Shaft of femur fracture
  • Posterior cruciate ligament injury

Other options:

Option a : A posteriorly directed force on the anterior aspect of the tibia is unlikely to cause an anterior cruciate ligament injury.

Options c : Medial collateral ligament injury occurs due to stress on the lateral knee during sports (valgus stress injury).

Option d : Lateral collateral ligament injury occurs due to stress on the medial aspect of the knee (varus stress injury).

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about FLAIR sequence imaging in MRI?

choices.text: Gives better visualisation of even small lesions

questions.solution:
The FLAIR sequence imaging shows lesions as hyperintense, not hypointense.  

FLAIR - Fluid Attenuated Inversion Recovery.  

In this 

  • Gray matter - Hyperintense
  • White matter - Hypointense
  • SF/Water - Hypointense
  • Lesions - appear Hyperintense  

It can detect even the smallest of lesions that can be missed in T2 Sequence though T2 is traditionally considered to be the window to detect pathology.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with swelling at the base of the thumb after falling on an outstretched hand while playing football.  Which of the following is most likely to be to be injured?
questions.solution:
The history of falls on the outstretched hands and swelling at the base of the thumb suggests the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture.

A scaphoid fracture is the most common carpal fracture. Direct axial compression or hyperextension of the wrist, such as with a fall onto an outstretched hand results in a scaphoid fracture.

Pain is localized to the radial aspect of the wrist proximal to the thumb metacarpal. Swelling may or may not be noticeable. Focal tenderness is usually present in one of three places - the volar prominence at the distal wrist crease,  or just distal to Lister's Tubercle.

The most common complications include nonunion, avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of the proximal fracture segment, and osteoarthritis. 

Diagnostic sign- precisely localized tenderness in the anatomical snuff box. 

X-ray of the wrist is taken but it has a high false-negative rate. Hence empiric splinting or MRI is recommended as the next step in such cases where clinical suspicion exists but X-ray findings are normal. Undisplaced fractures are managed by immobilization in a scaphoid cast applied in a glass-holding position. Reduction with compression screw is preferred for displaced fractures.

An oblique x-ray of the wrist should be able to show a scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child weighing 12 kg presents with loose motions. The child appears thirsty, irritable and eagerly drinks fluids. Tears are absent, and the skin pinch test returns slowly but does not take 2 seconds. Based on this presentation, what is the best treatment plan for this child?

choices.text: 200 ml ORS per episode of loose stool

questions.solution:
This child with a history of diarrhea who is irritable, thirsty, eager to drink, and has a slow skin turgor test (<2 sec) is suggestive of moderate dehydration.

The treatment of moderate dehydration is the administration of oral rehydration solution (ORS) of amount 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75) over 4 hours. Hence for a child of 12kg, the amount of ORS to be given is  900 ml of ORS over 4 hours (75 ml x 12 kg body weight).

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

 

Plan B: For moderate dehydration, the amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

 

Plan C: For severe dehydration, treatment includes IV fluid administration.

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the difference between quarantine and isolation?

choices.text: Quanrantine applies only to infected individuals
Quarantine applies to healthy contacts of infected cases
Isolation applies to healthy contacts of infected cases
Isolation does not apply to domestic animals

questions.solution:
Quarantine is defined as the limitation of freedom of movement of well-persons or animals, exposed to a communicable disease for a period of time not longer than the longest usual incubation period, to prevent contact with those not exposed.

In contrast, isolation is defined as the separation of infected persons or animal, for the period of communicability of the infection, to prevent direct or indirect transmission of the infection to those susceptible.

questions.text: A patient underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism. 1 year post surgery the following ECG changes were seen. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario the patient may have developed hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy as inferred from the ECG above showing a prolonged QT interval. 

This patient requires calcium supplementation. Continous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1 year post operatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia - mild circumoral or digital numbness and paresthesia, carpopedal spasm, or laryngeal spasms and cardiac arrhythmias. Chvostek and Trousseaus sign may be elicited. ECG changes may show QT prolongation or QRS changes.

Management - Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with IV and oral calcium and vitamin D replacement. 10 ml IV calcium gluconate 10% is given slowly. Supplemental Magnesium may also be required due to the synergestic actions of calcium and magnesium. 

Remember: Chvostek sign is facial nerve hyperactivity elicited by tapping over the common trunk of the facial nerve (anterior to the tragus) as it passes through the parotid gland

Trousseau sign (carpo-pedal spasm) is finger and wrist spasm after inflation of a blood pressure cuff for several minutes

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would not be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with irregularly irregular pulse points to a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation and the JVP finding seen would be absent a wave, not an absent y wave.

Atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia. There is rapid and irregular atrial activation which is transmitted through the atrioventricular node. The conducted ventricular rate is usually rapid and irregularly irregular. It can vary from 110-160 beats/minute. A pulse deficit is an important clinical finding associated with the condition. This arises due to preload reduction. 

The list of findings consistent with atrial fibrillation are as follows:

  • Absent p wave on ECG 
  • Absent a wave on JVP
  • Absent S4 (fourth heart sound) on auscultation
  • Absent presystolic accentuation in the patient of mitral stenosis on auscultation

Symptoms include palpitations, fatigue, presyncope, and dyspnea. An ECG shows the absence of P waves. 

In acute atrial fibrillation with hemodynamic instability, electrical or chemical cardioversion is the first step. The latter is done by intravenous administration of class III antiarrhythmic - ibutilide. In a stable patient, ventricular rate control is the primary aim. This is done by intravenous or oral administration of beta-blockers. Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil and diltiazem can also be used. 

If the current episode duration is >48 hours, cardioversion can precipitate thromboembolic complications. In such cases, cardioversion should be carried out only after 3 weeks of anticoagulation. It has to be continued for 4 weeks after cardioversion. Another option is to evaluate the presence of a thrombus in the left atrial appendage. This can be done either by transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) or high-resolution CT.

If the duration is <48 hours and there are no high-risk factors, cardioversion can be done. The CHA2DS2-VASc scoring system is used to assess stroke risk. 

Warfarin is recommended in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves who present with atrial fibrillation. In mitral stenosis, thrombi arise frequently from the dilated left atrium. Atrial fibrillation in the absence of mitral stenosis is known as nonvalvular atrial fibrillation. Oral factor Xa inhibitors such as apixaban, edoxaban, or rivaroxaban can be used in such cases.

questions.text: Which of the following findings do you expect to see in a patient with central diabetes insipidus?

choices.text: Low plasma osmolality  and low urine osmolality
High plasma osmolality and high urine osmolality
Low plasma osmolality and high urine osmolality
Low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality

questions.solution:
Diabetes insipidus of central or nephrogenic origin are characterized by low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality.

Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a syndrome characterized by the excretion of abnormally large volumes of dilute urine. The 24-hour urine volume exceeds 40 mL/kg body weight, and the 24-hour urine osmolarity is <280 mOsm/L. There will be a slight increase in plasma osmolarity/sodium that stimulates thirst (polydipsia). Hence, clinical symptoms and signs of dehydration are uncommon unless thirst and/or water intake are also impaired.

It can be central or nephrogenic.

  • Central DI occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH. It can be treated with desmopressin, an ADH analogue. 
  • In nephrogenic DI, ADH levels may be normal or increased because the kidney has become resistant to its effects. Nephrogenic DI requires treatment with a thiazide diuretic, amiloride, low sodium diet, and indomethacin. 

Condition

Plasma osmolality

Urine osmolality

Sodium concentration

Central and nephrogenic DI

High

Low

Hypernatremia

Psychogenic polydipsia

Low

Low

 Hyponatremia

SIADH

Low

High

Hyponatremia

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

Acquired

  • Head trauma (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Neoplasms
  • Granulomas
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Histiocytosis
  • Infectious
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Inflammatory
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  • Vascular
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)

Congenital

  • Malformations
  • Genetic
    • Wolfram syndrome

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is being evaluated for bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Ovarian Follicular cysts are least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding. They are usually asymptomatic unless they rupture, hemorrhage or the ovary undergoes torsion which would manifest as an acute abdomen. They occur when there is the failure of absorption of fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation. 

Postmenopausal bleeding is diagnosed when there is bleeding per vagina after 6 months of amenorrhoea after the age of 40 (menopausal age). 

Causes of postmenopausal bleeding include: 

  • Genital tract trauma (Option A)
  • Cervical erosion, inflammation, polyp, or ulcer
  • Uterus - endometritis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma (Option C), polyp, or sarcoma
  • Fallopian tube malignancy
  • Ovarian tumors such as Brenner tumor, granulosa cell tumor (Option D)
  • Hypertension and blood dyscrasia
  • Urinary tract trauma, bladder carcinoma
  • Hemorrhoid, anal fissures, and rectal cancers confused as bleeding per vagina
  • Use of estrogens as hormone replacement therapy, tamoxifen.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: A young sexually active male presented with multiple polypoid growths over his penis. Histopathological picture of an excised lesion is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows papillary (villous) architecture with acanthosis and koilocytosis of squamous epithelium, which are characteristic findings of condyloma acuminatum.

Condyloma acuminatum is a benign warty lesion that occurs in the anogenital region. It is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 (most frequent) and 11, which are sexually transmitted.

Grossly, they consist of single or multiple sessile or pedunculated, red papillary excrescences on the coronal sulcus and the inner surface of the prepuce.

Microscopically, the characteristic features include the following:

  • A branching villous structure with connective tissue stroma
  • Epidermis showing hyperkeratosis and acanthosis (thickening)
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolization of the squamous cells (koilocytosis) is characteristic of HPV infection.
  • No evident dysplasia

Other options:

  • Condyloma lata is a maculopapular/nodular lesion seen in secondary syphilis.
  • Bowen's disease is carcinoma in situ of penis is characterized by hyperproliferative epidermis and dysplastic epithelium.
  • Verrucous carcinoma, also known as very well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, shows hyperkeratotic and acanthotic papillae with a broad pushing base, keratin pearls, and dense inflammatory cell infiltrate.

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV serotype Lesions
HPV 6 and 11
  • Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts)
  • Sinonasal papilloma
  • Squamous papilloma of the larynx
HPV 16
  • LSIL, HSIL, carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Bowen disease (Carcinoma in situ of male external genitalia)
  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma
HPV 18
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma of the cervix
  • Carcinoma of the anogenital region
HPV 5 and 8
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin in epidermodysplasia verruciformis patients
   

 

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

questions.text: A man came with complaints of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of recurrent pain and discharge due to lesions around the anus, shown in the image is likely to be a fistula-in-ano.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal connection between the anal canal and the perianal skin, lined with granulation tissue. It may follow the drainage of a perianal abscess or may be seen in association with diseases like tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Clinical features are perianal pain, swelling, and intermittent purulent discharge, which might be blood-stained. On examination, one or more external openings may be visible.

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula. Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract. Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

 

 

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano can include a fistulogram, endoanal ultrasound with hydrogen peroxide, MRI, and computed tomography (CT) scan. An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. 

Surgical management includes fistulotomy, fistulectomy, ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT), setons, or advancement flaps.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of skin changes on his neck. The rash appears pigmented and scaly, particularly in areas exposed to sunlight as shown in the image given below.  Which of the following vitamins is primarily deficient in the condition represented by the skin changes seen in the photograph?
questions.solution:
This is an image of Casal's necklace which is seen in case of Pellagra which occurs in Niacin deficiency.

Casal's necklace:

  • So called as it forms a ring around the neck.
  • Characteristic skin rash that is pigmented and scaling, particularly in skin areas exposed to sunlight.
  • It is seen in advanced cases.

Pellagra:

  • Due to deficiency of Niacin (Vitamin B3).

Causes of Pellagra:

  • Dietary deficiency like corn based diet- maize and jowar
  • Alcoholics
  • Hartnup disease -  Congenital defects of intestinal and kidney absorption of tryptophan
  • Deficiency of micronutrients (e.g., iron, riboflavin, and pyridoxine)
  • Isoniazid can precipitate pellagra deficiency

Symptoms:

The primary manifestations of this syndrome are referred to as “the four D’s”:

  • Dermatitis
  • Diarrhea
  • Dementia
  • Death (if not treated)
  • Other features:
    • Bright red glossitis
    • Casals Necklace

Treatment:

Oral supplementation with 100 - 200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid - 5 days.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman conceived after being treated for infertility. Her USG scan is given below. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the twin peak sign which is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twins. This is also known as the lambda sign or delta sign.

In dichorionic twins, the intervening membrane between the twins has 4 layers i.e. 2 chorions and 2 amnions. The placenta protrudes from the base to the space between the 2 amnion layers. This gives rise to the twin peak sign i.e. triangle with the base at placenta and apex in the intervening membrane.

 

Sonographic assessment of dichorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Number of placental masses - 2
  • Presence of intervening membrane - twin peak or lambda or delta sign
  • Thickness of intervening membranes ≥ 2mm

The best time of delivery of dichorionic diamniotic twins is 38 weeks.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with ischemic heart disease and atrial fibrillation presents with sudden, severe, generalized abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. On examination, the pulse rate is 118 bpm, rhythm is irregularly irregular, and BP is 92/58 mm Hg. The abdomen appears soft, and non-distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia. For an acute arterial occlusive disease, the gold standard for diagnosis is angiography and that for management is laparotomy.

An embolus is the most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia. Risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are as follows:

  • Presence of an irregularly irregular pulse is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. 
  • Previous history of ischemic heart disease

The most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated symptoms can include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. With the onset of bowel infarction, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools occur.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of an acute arterial occlusive disease is angiography and that for management is laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to resect the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

questions.text: During laparoscopic hernia surgery in a male patient, a nerve located within the triangle of doom is injured. This nerve provides sensory innervation to which of the following regions?

choices.text: Anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament

questions.solution:
The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve is a content of the triangle of doom and can be injured in laparoscopic hernia surgery. The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve supplies sensation to the skin of the scrotum.

The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve provides nerve supply to:

  • Motor innervation to the cremaster muscle in males
  • Sensory innervation to:
    • The skin of the scrotum in males
    • Mons pubis and labia majora in females

The boundaries of the triangle of doom are:

  • Medially- ductus deferens
  • Laterally- gonadal vessels in the spermatic cord
  • Posteroinferiorly- peritoneal reflection
  • Apex- deep inguinal ring

The important contents of the triangle of doom include:

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerve

Other important surgical landmarks in this region are the triangle of pain and the crown of death.

The figure below shows the triangle of doom with its boundaries and contents-

Other options:

Option A: The suprapubic area is supplied by the iliohypogastric nerve and it can be injured following appendicectomy. It can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in a direct inguinal hernia.

Option B: The anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament is supplied by the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve.

Option D: The root of the penis is supplied by the ilioinguinal nerve.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and pain in the right iliac fossa. He had a history of nausea and vomiting 3 days back and was not taken to the hospital. The surgeon suggested percutaneous drainage as the CT of the right iliac fossa showed a well-circumscribed fluid collection.  What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
The history of right iliac fossa pain with fever, nausea, and vomiting is suggestive of acute appendicitis, which in this case has progressed to an appendicular abscess as suggested by the radiological findings.

An appendicular abscess is a very common complication of an untreated or perforated appendix. It can occur retroperitoneally or intraperitoneally.

Investigations include USG or CT of the abdomen which shows a well-circumscribed, rounded, or ill-defined, irregular fluid collection in the appendicular region. 

With the recent advances, early laparoscopic drainage or radiologically assisted percutaneous drainage followed by delayed appendicectomy is also done. If these are unsuccessful or there is leakage into the peritoneal cavity a midline laparotomy can be done. 

Note:

The popular management of an appendicular mass is the Oschner-Sherren regime which is conservative management as the inflammatory process has already been localized and surgery is complicated now. 

If it progresses to an abscess, it must be drained radiologically or laparoscopically along with intravenous antibiotics.

The indications for stopping the conservative management include:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain 
  • The increasing size of the mass.

A follow-up CT is taken in case of conservative management to ensure that there is a complete resolution of the inflammatory process.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the respiratory clinic with complaints of chronic cough, occasional hemoptysis, and persistent chest pain. On examination, decreased breath sounds are noted in the left lower lung field. A chest X-ray shows the presence of a Monod sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The Monod sign, observed on chest X-ray, refers to the presence of gas surrounding a mass within a pulmonary cavity. This finding is characteristic of aspergilloma, also known as a fungal ball, which typically consists of Aspergillus fungus and forms within pre-existing cavities in the lung

Monod sign:

  • Monod sign refers to the presence of gas surrounding a mass within a pulmonary cavity.
  • The fungal ball can be seen on both plain film and CT as an intracavitary mass surrounded by a crescent of air.
  • Aspergillomas are mass-like fungus balls that are typically composed of Aspergillus fumigatus and are a non-invasive form of pulmonary aspergillosis.
  • Aspergillomas occur in patients with normal immunity but structurally abnormal lungs, with pre-existing cavities.
  • Most common underlying condition is pulmonary tuberculosis.

Other clinical manifestations of Aspergillus:

  • The halo sign in chest imaging is a feature seen on HRCT where ground glass opacity surrounding a pulmonary nodule or mass and represents haemorrhage. It is typically seen in angioinvasive aspergillosis. Seen in immunocompromised patients.
  • Below image depicts CT halo sign in invasive aspergillosis.
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis – both a Type1 and Type 3 immune reaction. The image depicts gloved finger appearance of Simon of ABPA in left upper lobe. It is a characteristic sign of bronchocele.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. Hysterectomy was performed and the following specimen was  retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The specimen is of a Leiomyoma.

The uterine body / corpus is enlarged and deformed. The cut surface shows multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, white-greyish with a whorled appearance formed by the intersecting bundles of brown muscle fibers and white fibrous tissue. Leiomyomas can also present bleeding areas, cystic degeneration and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.

Menstrual symptoms of fibroid includes:

  • Menorrhagia, polymenorrhoea, metrorrhagia, continuous or postmenopausal bleeding
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Infertility, recurrent abortions
  • Pain
  • Pressure symptoms
  • Abdominal lump
  • Vaginal discharge

Drugs to reduce the size of the fibroid:

  • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone/RU-486
  • Danazol (Usually not used due to androgenic side effects)
  • GnRH 
    • Agonists – goserelin, leuprorelin, nafarelin, busereli
    • Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix
  • Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM’s) – Ulipristal, Asoprisnil

Other medical methods to treat fibroids include:

  • Levonorgestrel IUD- controls bleeding effectively
  • Combined oral contraceptives
  • DMPA
  • Tranexamic acid
  • Iron therapy for anemia
  • Selective estrogen-receptor modulators (SERMs) like tibolone and raloxifene are used as add-back therapy along with GnRH treatment. They reduce associated vasomotor symptoms and bone loss.

Radiological interventions for fibroids:

  • Uterine artery Embolization - Angiographic interventional procedure where polyvinyl alcohol microspheres are introduced into both uterine arteries, producing ischemia and necrosis of the fibroid.
  • Magnetic Resonance guided Focused Ultrasound - Ultrasound energy is focused to cause coagulative necrosis in selected fibroids.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy

  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration

  • Red degeneration

  • Sarcomatous change

  • Torsion, hemorrhage

  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp

  • Inversion of the uterus

  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma

  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia

  • Accompanying adenomyosis

  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: A patient after careful evaluation was found to have a chronic inflammatory condition of the bowel with lesions involving the colon and rectum in a continuous manner. Which of the following serological markers is positive in the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) positivity is a feature of ulcerative colitis. 

Ulcerative Colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease that primarily affects the rectum and extends proximally to involve the colon. Patients typically present with diarrhoea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, crampy abdominal pain, and mucus discharge. They may also present with anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Barium enema in Ulcerative Colitis shows complete loss of haustral markings in the diseased section of the colon, and the organ appears smooth-walled and cylindrical, giving it the appearance of a lead pipe. Diagnosis can be made by colonoscopy followed by a biopsy. Salazopyrine/Sulfasalazine and Mesalamine (5 ASA) are used in first-line therapy of UC. Steroids are used in refractory cases.

ASCA (anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody), anti-pancreatic antibody, and anti-flagellin antibody positivity are seen in Crohn's disease.

Serological Markers in IBD
Crohn's disease  Ulcerative colitis

ASCA

OMP-C 

Anti I2 

Anti-pancreatic antibody

Anti-flagellin antibody

p-ANCA

Anti-goblet cell Antibody

questions.text: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above which you perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
The finding of an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm requires further evaluation (i.e., a biopsy of the endometrium).

If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm, then malignancy is rare and there is no need of a biopsy.

The cutoff point of endometrial thickness is controversial. But, according to the ACOG guidelines, it is more than 4mm.

questions.text: The most common leukemia in children with Down syndrome is _____.
questions.solution:
The most common leukemia in children with Down’s syndrome is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk of both acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Note:

  • Most common leukemia in Down's syndrome: B-cell Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL)
  • Most common AML in Down's syndrome: M7/megakaryoblastic

10% of neonates with Down's syndrome develop transient leukemia or myeloproliferative disorder. These features usually resolve within the 1st 3 months of life. However, they require close follow-up, because 20–30% will develop typical leukemia (often acute megakaryocytic leukemia) by 3 years of life (AML is more common during first 3 years of life )

questions.text: A patient with increased blood pressure on evaluation was found to have low serum potassium levels along with an arterial blood gas analysis report showing a picture of alkalosis. A diagnosis of Liddle syndrome is made. Identify the drug which can be used for the treatment of this condition.
questions.solution:
Amiloride is used for the treatment of Liddle syndrome.

Liddle's syndrome is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension.

It is an autosomal dominant condition due to a gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene. This gene codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. This leads to increased sodium retention and results in a state of pseudo-hyperaldosteronism. The following findings are seen:

  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis
  • Normal-low aldosterone
  • Low renin 

Treatment is with diuretics that directly block the ENaC channels, like amiloride and triamterene. Spironolactone is not effective as it is an aldosterone-receptor antagonist.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: When do you consider administering epinephrine in a neonate during resuscitation?

choices.text: Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations
Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations
Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask  ventilation
Infants with severe respiratory depression fail to respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask

questions.solution:
If the heart rate remains at <60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilation, consider administering IV epinephrine in neonatal resuscitation.

The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate.
  • HR < 100:  Positive Pressure Ventilation, SPO2 monitoring
  • HR < 60: chest compressions at a rate of 90 compressions/min 
  • HR still remains <60: IV epinephrine 

Note: Umbilical venous catheter is the preferred method of obtaining emergency vascular access in the delivery room.

questions.text: In a modern sewage treatment plant, a light green oxidized flocculent material is formed after secondary treatment with the trickling filter method. This material is called____.
questions.solution:
The light green oxidized sewage formed after secondary treatment (trickling filter method) is called humus. It is then led toward the secondary sedimentation.

Other options:

Option B: Sludge is the organic matter that settles down in the tank during the sedimentation step of the primary treatment of sewage.

Option C: The effluent, formed from the primary sedimentation tank, contains a proportion of organic matter in solution or colloidal state and numerous living organisms.

Option D: Sullage is the waste water that doesn't contain human excreta.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient with chronic kidney disease is planned for dialysis treatment. All of the following statements are true about dialysis except.

choices.text: Uremic encephalopathy can be an indication of dialysis
Cardiovascular related deaths are more common among those on dialysis than transplant recipients
The most common acute complication of hemodialysis is hypotension
Peritoneal dialysis is executed by creating an anastomosis of an artery to a vein

questions.solution:
Hemodialysis, not peritoneal dialysis is executed by creating an anastomosis of an artery to a vein. In peritoneal dialysis, a peritoneal catheter is used to gain access into the peritoneal cavity to carry out dialysis.

Dialysis is a form of renal replacement therapy. Here the kidney's function of blood filtration is supplemented with artificial equipment to remove excess water, solutes, and toxins.

Dialysis broadly has three types that include hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis and continuous renal replacement therapy.

Indications for dialysis include: 

  • Refractory metabolic acidosis that has failed to respond to medical treatment
  • Refractory hyperkalemia 
  • Extracellular volume expansion despite diuretic therapy
  • Uremic symptoms (encephalopathy)
  • eGFR <10 mL/min per 1.73 m2 
  • Any toxic ingestions

Contraindications for dialysis include inability to secure vascular access, needle phobia, cardiac failure and coagulopathy.

For patients with ESKD(End-stage kidney disease) in the long term, cardiovascular disorders are considered the major cause of death. Notably, cardiovascular-related deaths are more common among those on dialysis than transplant recipients (Option B).

The most common acute complication of hemodialysis is Intradialytic hypotension (Option C).

questions.text: A male infant presented with distension of abdomen shortly after birth with history of not passing meconium. Subsequently a barium enema was done and given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts barium enema showing dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid descending colon characteristic of Hirschsprung's disease.

The most important sign on barium enema is a sudden change of caliber from the narrow aganglionic segment and dilated proximal bowel.

  • Hirschsprung disease is characterised by aganglionosis (absence of ganglion cells) in the distal colon and rectum.
  • It is thought to either occur from a failure of neuroblasts in neural crest cells to migrate into bowel segments or degeneration of already migrated neuroblasts.
  • It affects cells both in the myenteric and submucosal plexuses. Hence, functional obstruction develops as a result of a spasm in the denervated colon.

questions.text: Identify the suture material.
questions.solution:
Plain catgut is yellowish absorbable suture material.

Chromic catgut is brownish.

Option A: Vicryl is violet colored absorbable suture material.

Option D: Silk is black colored, multifilament, natural, braided, and non absorbable suture material derived from cocoon of silkworm larva.

questions.text: Which is not true about the surgical position shown in the image?

choices.text: It is the best surgical position for CNS procedures specially posterior fossa surgeries
It ensures a relatively bloodless field during surgery
It can also be used for breast reconstruction
It decreases the risk of air embolism during surgery

questions.solution:
The image shows a person lying in the supine position, with the upper torso at 90o. This is the Fowlers position.

The fowlers position increases the risk of air embolism during surgery.

Fowlers position:

  • It is the best surgical position for CNS procedures especially posterior fossa surgeries
  • It ensures a relatively bloodless field during surgery
  • It can also be used for breast reconstruction.

questions.text: Identify the type of ovarian tumor in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows cut specimen of ovary with hair and sebum – Dermoid cyst which is a germ cell tumor.

Dermoid cyst

  • A benign teratoma
  • Most common benign tumor of ovary in reproductive age group
  • Most common benign tumor of ovary diagnosed in pregnancy
  • Most common germ cell tumor (overall)
  • It is the commonest tumor to undergo torsion.
  • It is bilateral in 10-15% cases.
  • Rokitansky’s protuberance, which is a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands along with teeth & bones can be seen.
  • Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological study – known as Struma Ovarii.
  • Most common tissue elements found are ectodermal derivatives.

questions.text:
Triple assessment includes

1. History
2. Clinical examination
3. Radiological investigations
4. Histopathological examination
questions.solution:
Triple assessment in relation to breast carcinoma includes the following:

  • History and clinical examination
  • Radiological imaging, including ultrasonography (USG) and/or mammography
  • Histopathological examination (HPE), including fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) and/or Tru-Cut biopsy

The positive predictive value of the triple assessment is 99.9%.

Note: In Bailey & Love 27th Ed, Pg 863, it is mentioned that clinical assessment, radiological imaging, and HPE constitute triple assessment. However, clinical assessment includes both history and clinical examination. Hence, history is a part of triple assessment.

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman presents with heat intolerance and fine tremors in both her hands for 6 months. She also complains of palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities. Examination revealed a BP of 136/86 mm Hg, tachycardia, and exophthalmos. Which of the statements is true in this patient?

RAIU - Radioactive Iodine Uptake

choices.text: RAIU at 24 hours is below normal

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient's symptoms point toward hyperthyroidism, and eye findings like exophthalmos are highly suggestive of Graves' disease. In this condition, the serum TSH is low, unbound T4 is high, and T3 is high. 

Graves disease is an autoimmune disease with a strong familial predisposition (50%) and females are at a higher risk with a peak incidence between the ages of 40-60 years. The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is due to stimulatory autoantibodies i.e Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) to TSH-R. Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) binds to and activates the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor resulting in diffuse toxic goiter and therefore, increased T4 and T3 levels. The clinical features include:

Symptoms:

  • Hyperactivity,  irritability, dysphoria
  • Heat intolerance and sweating
  • Palpitations
  • Fatigue and weakness
  • Weight loss with increased appetite
  • Diarrhea
  • Polyuria
  • Oligomenorrhea,  loss of libido

Signs:

  • Tachycardia, atrial fibrillation in the elderly
  • Tremor
  • Goiter
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Muscle weakness, proximal myopathy
  • Lid retraction or lag
  • Gynecomastia
  • Extra thyroidal conditions include ophthalmopathy, dermopathy (pretibial myxedema), thyroid acropachy, gynecomastia, and other manifestations.

Diagnosis:

  • Lab Investigations:
    • T4 and T3 increased due to the stimulating effect of TSI on the TSH receptors.
    • TSH is reduced as increased T4 levels in the blood lead to negative feedback on TRH in the hypothalamus.
    • Elevated TSH-R antibodies- diagnostic
    • Anti-Tg and anti-TPO are seen but nonspecific
  • Radiological investigations:
    • RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake) at 24 hours is characteristically above normal due to increased thyroid hormone production.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic for check-up following an MTP. On ultrasound, retained tissue was found and the following instrument was used for its removal. What is this instrument?
questions.solution:
The image shows a manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) syringe.

Manual vacuum aspiration can be safely done upto 12 weeks of gestation. However, WHO recommends it as the procedure of choice for MTP only upto 10 weeks of gestation . 

The indications of this procedure are given as follows:

  • Medical termination of pregnancy
  • Incomplete abortion or missed abortion
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Endometrial aspiration
