questions.text: Split thickness skin graft for wound closure on thigh includes:

choices.text: Epidermis and variable parts of dermis

questions.solution:
Split thickness skin graft for wound closure on thigh includes epidermis and variable parts of the dermis.

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts.

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft): include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or electric dermatome.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is a contraindication in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donors to full-thickness defects.
  • The donor area is dressed appropriately and the dressing is opened after 10 days and not earlier. 

The given image shows Humby's knife. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humbys knife is 0.3 mm.

Related Pearl: Skin graft : phases of uptake of the graft

The take of skin graft occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): during the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation, in which cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses
  3. Neovascularization, in which blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft

Sensibility returns to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, with light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition,revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced by postgraft day 7 with fibroblasts)

questions.text: You are reviewing a young female in the Intensive Care Unit who came with complaints of ascending paralysis. Guillian-Barré syndrome (GBS) was suspected. Now you notice that she has developed difficulty in breathing.  Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows very low pO2 and high pCO2 levels. What is the type of respiratory failure seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of Guillian-Barré syndrome(GBS) with hypoxemia and hypercapnia is suggestive of type 2 respiratory failure. 

Type II respiratory failure occurs as a consequence of alveolar hypoventilation and results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively. The mechanism of type II respiratory failure in Guillian-Barré syndrome can be due to impaired neuromuscular transmission.

Reduced strength for respiration can be due to impaired neuromuscular transmission (e.g., myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barré syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) or respiratory muscle weakness (e.g., myopathy, electrolyte derangements, fatigue) or diminished CNS drive to breathe (Drug overdose, brainstem injury, sleep-disordered breathing, and severe hypothyroidism).

Treatment:

  • Reversing the underlying causes of ventilatory failure
  • Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation with a tight-fitting facial or nasal mask (avoidance of endotracheal intubation)

Guillian-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute, autoimmune polyneuropathy. The usual presentation is symmetrical, ascending paralysis evolving over hours to a few days. The legs are usually more affected than the arms. Lower cranial nerves are also frequently involved, causing bulbar weakness and difficulty in maintaining an airway and handling secretions. Deep tendon reflexes also attenuate or disappear within a few days of onset. 

Other options:

Option A: Type IV respiratory failure occurs due to hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles during shock. Intubation and mechanical ventilation can cause a redistribution of cardiac output to vital organs.

Option B: Type III respiratory failure results from lung atelectasis. It is more common in the postoperative period. Treatment includes frequent changes in position, chest physiotherapy, upright positioning, and control of incisional and/or abdominal pain. Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation may also be used to reverse regional atelectasis.

Option C: Type I respiratory failure (acute hypoxemic type) occurs due to alveolar flooding (caused by alveolar haemorrhage, pulmonary oedema, lung injury, pneumonia) and subsequent ventilation-perfusion mismatch and intrapulmonary shunt physiology. Examples: Sepsis, COVID-19, Gastric aspiration, pneumonia, near-drowning.

Related Pearl: Types of respiratory failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I

Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure

(Low paO2 only)

 Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology.
  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Lung injury and alveolar hemorrhage
  • Pneumonia
  • Acute severe asthma
  • Other causes: Sepsis, gastric aspiration, near-drowning, multiple blood transfusions, and pancreatitis.
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

(Low paO2, High PaCO2)

 Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.
  • Respiratory center: brainstem injury, severe hypothyroidism, sleep apnoea, sedative drug overdose.
  • Chest wall and neuromuscular: Kyphoscoliosis, ankylosing spondylitis, myasthenia gravis, motor neuron disease, myopathy, fatigue.
  • Lung: COPD, pleural pathology, foreign body obstruction.
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: You are evaluating a 17-year-old boy for Marfan's syndrome. You notice the following appearance of the chest as shown in the image below. This finding is called:
questions.solution:
The given image shows forward protrusion of the sternum and the adjacent costal cartilages. This finding is called pectus carinatum.

Pectus carinatum is also known as pigeon chest. It is seen in conditions such as Marfan’s syndrome, rickets, and childhood asthma.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by a mutation in the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene on the long arm of chromosome 15. Skeletal manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include:

  • Tall stature and long limbs; upper segment to lower segment ratio is reduced.
  • Pectus carinatum 
  • Pectus excavatum or cobbler chest or funnel chest 
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Joint laxity 

The image given below shows the pectus excavatum, characterized by an increased hollowness in the lower part of the sternum.

 

The images below show two important signs seen in Marfan's syndrome: 

  • Image a shows positive wrist sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist
  • Image b shows positive thumb sign - the thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist.

 

Cardiovascular manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include mitral valve prolapse progressing to mitral regurgitation, aortic root dilation leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture. Ocular manifestations include ectopia lentis, where there is upward and temporal dislocation of the lens and myopia.

Other options: 

Option B: Harrison’s sulcus refers to the indrawing of ribs resulting in horizontal grooves along the lower border of the chest due to the pulling of the diaphragm on a weak chest wall. It occurs in chronic respiratory disease in childhood, childhood asthma, and rickets.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic at 17 weeks of gestational age with a lump of 2 X 2 cm in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast, from 3 months. Which of the following investigations would you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present with a breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and is able to detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes.

USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 40 years) since breast tissue is dense in these populations.

Other options:

Mammography (option A) is less useful in pregnant women due to the increased density of breast tissue.

MRI (option B) MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in cases where metastasis or spread to other breast is suspected.

Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) (option D) is not recommended in pregnant women. It is difficult to distinguish breast cancer from the normal cellular proliferation in the breast tissue due to the hormonal changes.

questions.text: The most common cause of obstetrical hemorrhage is ______
questions.solution:
Uterine atony is the most common cause of obstetrical hemorrhage.

Uterine atony is the failure of uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery and to arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site.

Types of PPH:

  • Primary: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of child birth.
    • Most common cause: Atonic PPH
  • Secondary: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and upto 12 weeks Post partum
    • Most common cause: Retained placenta

Causes of PPH (Mnemonic: 4’T’)

  • T- Tone: Atonic PPH
  • T-Trauma: Traumatic PPH
  • T-Thrombin:Coagulopathy (DIC and hypofibrinogenemia)
  • T-Tissue:retained products of conception.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with easy fatiguability, weight loss, and anorexia. On examination, he is found to have generalised lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. The total leucocyte count is 1 lakh per microliter, with 80% lymphocytes. The peripheral smear shows increased lymphocytes with many smudge cells. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 65-year-old male patient with hepatosplenomegaly, increased WBC count with characteristic smudge cells on the peripheral smear is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukaemia.

Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) is a peripheral B-cell neoplasm usually affecting adults, more commonly men. It is asymptomatic at diagnosis, but some features include easy fatigability, weight loss, anorexia, generalised lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anaemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells; leukocyte count is variable. 

A lymph node biopsy in CLL reveals small lymphocytes mixed with varying numbers of larger, activated lymphocytes that frequently cluster in proliferation centres. These centres, containing mitotically active cells, are considered pathognomonic for CLL.

Peripheral smear shows predominantly small lymphocytes with smudge cells/ basket cells or parachute cells. It is given below.

Other options :

Option A: Chronic myeloid Leukemia(CML) is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder and it occurs due to the translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, forming the Philadelphia chromosome. The image below shows peripheral smear findings of CML with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

Option C: Mantle cell lymphoma usually presents in the 5th to 6th decades of life and shows a male predominance. The most common presentation is painless lymphadenopathy. On HP examination, homogeneous small lymphocytes with irregular/deeply cleaved nuclear contours are seen. The image given below shows a histopathology slide depicting mantle cell lymphoma:

Option D: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts.

Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female patient presents with bilateral weakness of the shoulders and hips. She noticed a rash on the extensor surface of her hands, knees, and ankles. She has a rash over her anterior torso as depicted in the image below.  What is the name of the finding given in the image?
questions.solution:
The name of the finding in the image is the V sign. The patient likely has dermatomyositis, a type of inflammatory myopathy. 

Dermatomyositis is characterized by symmetrical involvement of the muscles, commonly affecting the proximal muscles more than the distal muscles. It is also accompanied by multiple dermatological manifestations:

  • Shawl sign (Option B)- rashes that occur in a sun-exposed area. This is present on the back of the neck and shoulders. 
  • V sign - rashes that occur in sun-exposed areas. They are present on the anterior neck and chest 
  • Heliotrope rash (Option D) is erythema and discoloration of the eyelids with periorbital edema.
  • Gottron's sign (Option A) is an erythematous rash on the elbows, knees, ankles, and knuckles, on the extensor surfaces.
  • Gottron's papules are raised erythematous rashes over the knuckles. 
  • Edema of face and limbs
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Vasculopathic ulcers
  • Mechanic's hands in antisynthetase syndrome
  • Poikiloderma
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

Other manifestations of dermatomyositis include dysphagia, interstitial lung disease, bronchopneumonia, alveolitis, and myocarditis. 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy and immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis is immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids as the first line. Methotrexate can be started as the second line if the patient presents with severe weakness, other organ system involvement, or those with risk of steroid complications like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women. Otherwise, second-line agents are only started in patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose. Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required. 

The image given below is heliotrope rash:

The image below shows the Shawl sign. 

The image below shows the Gottron's papules and Gottron's sign respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following radioactive tracer tests be used to rule out the false positives caused by solid thyroid nodules?
questions.solution:
A thyroid-specific tracer like 99Tc- Pertechnetate could be used to rule out the false positives caused by the solid thyroid nodules. 

The Sestamibi scanning is a nuclear-based imaging test used to localize the Parathyroid glands. Sestamibi accumulates in the Mitochondria and therefore washes out at differential rates depending on the number of mitochondria in individual tissue. Parathyroid adenomas often have a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content, hence retain tracers and therefore have a slow washout compared to the thyroid gland. The false positives that might arise because of the highly oxyphilic lesion like Hürthle cell nodules can be reduced by the addition of thyroid-specific radioactive tracer 99Tc-pertechnetate and subsequent subtraction images.

questions.text: The risk of malignancy in “cold” lesions detected on radionuclide thyroid scanning is:
questions.solution:
The risk of malignancy is higher in “cold” lesions (15-20%) as compared to “warm” lesions (<5%).

A thyroid scan is used in patients with hyperthyroidism i.e. low TSH.

A cold nodule indicates reduced function whereas a hot nodule indicates an increased function in that part of the gland. 

Hot nodules are rarely malignant and are further managed with either I131 or surgery.

Cold nodules need to be further evaluated using USG as they pose a higher risk of malignancy.

questions.text: A man presents to the ER with a gunshot wound to the abdomen as shown below. On examination, the peritoneum is breached. BP is 114/78 mmHg and HR is 80 bpm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for a patient with a gunshot wound to the anterior abdominal wall with a breach of the peritoneum is laparotomy.

The incidence of significant injury to the intraperitoneal organs increases manifold when there is a breach of the peritoneum due to any penetrating trauma injury. The indications for doing laparotomy in patients with penetrating abdominal wounds include:

  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Gunshot wound which breaches the peritoneum
  • Evisceration
  • Bleeding from the stomach, rectum, or genitourinary tract following penetrating trauma
  • Peritonitis
  • Free air in the peritoneal cavity
  • Diagnostic peritoneal lavage has bile, gastrointestinal contents or ≥10 cc of blood

CT scan of the abdomen (option B) should be performed in patients with blunt or penetrating abdominal trauma, provided they are hemodynamically stable and have no indication for immediate laparotomy. The patient in question has a gunshot wound to the anterior abdominal wall with a peritoneal breach, which is an indication for exploratory laparotomy as it carries a high risk of organ injury. FAST (option C) is primarily indicated in patients with blunt abdominal trauma with or without hemodynamic instability. It is not a sensitive investigation to detect hollow visceral injury in patients with penetrating abdominal trauma. There is no role for observation (option D) in this patient.

questions.text: A patient with a decreased urine output came to the nephrology outpatient department. Urine analysis revealed broad, waxy casts. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Broad, waxy casts are features of Chronic renal failure.

Casts in Urine:

  • Hyaline cast: Normal physiological conditions, fever, exercise, prerenal failure
  • RBC cast: Glomerular injury
  • WBC cast: Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis
  • Muddy-brown granular cast: Acute tubular necrosis
  • Broad cast: Chronic renal failure

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: You are volunteering in a vaccination camp. You perform a shake test before administering a particular vaccine. Which of the following is checked by this test?
questions.solution:
The shake test is done to check for damage to vaccines that are sensitive to freezing temperatures.

Steps to perform the shake test:

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than that in the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze-sensitive. These include vaccines against:

  • Diphtheria
  • Tetanus
  • Pertussis
  • Haemophilus influenza type b (Liquid )
  • Hepatitis B

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: The given image is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a classical fish mouth (microstomia) appearance seen in systemic sclerosis/scleroderma.

Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features are seen in Scleroderma:

  • Severe pruritus
  • Initially, puffiness and non-pitting edema of fingers
  • The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly
  • Vasospasm and digital ulceration
  • Most patients have dysphagia and GERD
  • Mask-like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis 
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Other options:

Option B: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis. ANA, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith antibodies are positive in SLE. 

Option C: Angular stomatitis is the soreness at the angles of the mouth extending outwards in the folds of the facial skin.

Option D: Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is caused by coxsackievirus. It is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs.

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the psychiatrist by his wife. The patient accuses his wife of cheating on him despite the wife denying it. The patient constantly keeps checking his wife's phone and has hacked into her social media account on multiple occasions previously. The wife says that the patient has become very jealous and insecure. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient is suffering from Othello syndrome. It is a rare psychiatric condition marked by morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy. Eg: Suspecting a faithful partner of infidelity, with accompanying jealousy.

DELUSIONAL MISIDENTIFICATION SYNDROMES

Capgras syndrome: The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Fregoli’s syndrome: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people/strangers are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Syndrome of intermetamorphosis: A very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will.

Doppleganger syndrome: A person feels he has his own impostor(duplicate) – Delusion of subjective doubles.

This is a recent AIIMS question. Named delusions and themes of delusions are repeatedly being asked in AIIMS as well as NEET examination. A good understanding of this high yield topic will be helpful.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the pediatrician's office for a routine check-up. The infant's mother reports a history of congenital heart disease in the family, and upon examination, the paediatrician notices cyanosis and clubbing of the infant's fingers. Further evaluation reveals a heart murmur. He is suspected to have pentalogy of Fallot. Which of the following is a component of this condition?
questions.solution:
The pentalogy of Fallot includes the classic features of Tetralogy of Fallot (ventricular septal defect, pulmonic stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy) along with the presence of an atrial septal defect. Therefore, atrial septal defect is a component of the pentalogy of Fallot, distinguishing it from the classic tetralogy.

Pentalogy of Fallot =

  • Tetralogy of Fallot: Ventricular septal defect + Pulmonic stenosis + Overriding of the aorta + Right ventricular hypertrophy (+)
  • Atrial septal defect

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of leukemia presents to the emergency department with complaints of weakness, nausea, and confusion. The patient recently started chemotherapy for his leukemia. On examination, the patient appears lethargic with signs of dehydration. Laboratory investigations are ordered to assess his electrolyte levels. Which of the following findings will NOT be seen in this patient as a complication of chemotherapy-induced cell lysis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has tumour lysis syndrome, and hypercalcemia is not seen in this condition.

Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It most commonly occurs after the initiation of chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

TLS is characterized by

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia 
  • Acidosis
  • Acute renal failure

The management of TLS includes aggressive hydration along with allopurinol. Febuxostat a selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, and rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase can be used to treat hyperuricemia. Hypocalcemia is not treated unless it is symptomatic, to avoid metastatic calcifications. Patients with renal impairment are managed with hemodialysis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about sex chromatin is false?

choices.text: The number of Barr bodies in someone with 47XXY genetic makeup is two
Barr body may be seen in a genetic male
Drumstick shaped mass of chromatin in neutrophil nucleus is called Davidson body
A site for sampling for sex chromatin is the buccal mucosa

questions.solution:
The number of Barr bodies in someone with 47XXY genetic makeup is one, not two. 

  • The number of Barr bodies is one lesser than the number of X chromosomes.
  • Barr body is a small planoconvex mass, lying near the nuclear membrane; it represents the inactivated X chromosome. 
  • Barr bodies are seen in 0-4% of genetic males (46XY) and 20-80% of genetic females (46XX).
  • Sites for sampling for sex chromatin : Buccal mucosa, tooth pulp, hair bulb.
  • Davidson body is a drumstick shaped mass of chromatin hanging down from neutrophil nuclei; it is seen only in females (0-6%).

questions.text: A newborn presents with a midline defect in the lower abdominal wall as shown below. Which of the following can be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a midline defect situated in the lower abdominal region below the umbilicus with an exposed bladder is suggestive of ectopia vesicae/ bladder exstrophy. The condition can be associated with a bifid clitoris in females. 

Ectopia vesicae/ bladder exstrophy is a congenital abdominal wall defect wherein the bladder protrudes from the lower abdominal wall and its mucosa is exposed. This results in the separation of the pubic rami and the rectus muscles. 

The condition can be associated with complete epispadias with dorsal chordee, undescended testes, and inguinal hernias in males. Females may also have epispadias and separation of the two halves of the clitoris (bifid clitoris). The condition can be associated with rectal prolapse and short stature in both sexes.

Untreated exstrophy can cause urinary incontinence and is associated with an increased incidence of bladder cancer. Management involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia.

Other options: 

Trisomy 18 (option A), Wilms' tumor (option C), and meningomyelocele (option D) can be associated with omphalocele. Omphalocele is another congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the umbilicus causing herniation of the abdominal contents into the base of the umbilical cord. The herniated viscera is covered with peritoneum without any overlying skin. This condition can be associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome which is associated with embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor. 

The image below shows an omphalocele:

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of chest pain at rest for 6 hours and ECG suggestive of Myocardial Ischemia. Which among the following is used for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Measurement of LDH1 is suggestive of Myocardial Ischemia as it is seen predominantly in the heart.

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)

  • Normally, serum levels of LDH2 are greater than those of LDH1; but, in MI, LDH1 is more than LDH2. This is called flipping of the LDH ratio.

  • LDH: A tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (Heart) and M isoform (Muscle)

    • LDH-1: Heart.
    • LDH-2: Blood.
    • LDH-3: Brain, kidney, lungs, spleen, pancreas.
    • LDH-4: Liver and skeletal muscle.
    • LDH-5: Liver and skeletal muscle.
  • Current recommendations suggest that LDH no longer has a role in the diagnosis of MI.

The other cardiac biomarkers are:

Troponin T and Troponin I

  • These are the proteins that mediate calcium-mediated contraction of the cardiac and skeletal muscles.
  • They are highly specific for MI.
  • Troponin I is more important than troponin T.
  • Troponins will remain elevated longer than creatine kinase (CK), for up to 14 days.
  • This makes troponins a superior marker for diagnosing MI in the recent past (late diagnosis).
  • Reinfarction: It is now clear that cardiac troponin (cTn) increases rapidly, even if it is from an abnormal baseline in patients with reinfarction.
  • If the cTn concentration is elevated, but stable or decreasing at the time of suspected reinfarction, the diagnosis of reinfarction requires a 20% or greater increase in the cTn measurement

Creatine kinase (CK).

  • It is less sensitive than troponins.
  • When cTn is available, CK-MB should not be used for the initial diagnosis of acute MI.
  • If it is the only assay available, it can be used, but it is far less sensitive and specific.

Myoglobin

  • It is the earliest enzyme to increase after MI.
  • Myoglobin is a protein found in the skeletal and cardiac muscles, which binds oxygen.
  • It is a very sensitive indicator of muscle injury.
  • However, it is not specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle.
  • The rise in myoglobin can help to determine the size of infarction.

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers of Myocardial Injury

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d

questions.text: A man continues to call women, and achieves sexual gratification by talking obscenity and sharing obscene pictures. This condition is termed as ________.
questions.solution:
Telephone and computer scatology- it involves obscene phone calling or sending of inappropriate videos/images to an unsuspecting person.

Paraphilias or perversions are sexual stimuli or acts that are deviations from normal sexual behaviors but are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm.

Important paraphilic disorders are:

  • Exhibitionism- Urge to expose genitals to a stranger or unsuspecting person.
  • Fetishism- It is the use of objects for sexual gratification. Eg. shoes, gloves, pantyhose, and stockings. The objects can be used to attain gratification directly or the person may ask the partner to wear them during sexual intercourse.
  • Frotteurism- is usually characterized by a man's rubbing his penis against the buttocks or other body parts of a fully clothed woman to achieve orgasm.
  • Pedophilia- involves recurrent intense sexual urges or arousal by children less than 13 years of age over a period of at least 6 months.
  • Masochism- takes its name from the activities of Leopold von Sacher-Masoch, a novelist whose characters derived sexual pleasure from being abused and dominated by women.
  • Sexual sadism- The person attains sexual arousal from the physical and psychosocial suffering of another person.
  • Voyeurism- It is also called scoptophilia. The person has an urge to watch an unsuspecting person naked or in sexual activity.
  • Transvestism- Fantasies and sexual urge to dress in opposite gender clothing.
  • Telephone and computer scatology- it involves obscene phone calling or sending of video images to an unsuspecting partner. 
  • Necrophilia- it is an obsession with obtaining sexual gratification from dead bodies
  • Zoophilia- having an urge to involve in sexual activity like intercourse, masturbation, or oral-genital contact with an animal.
  • Coprophilia- Sexual pleasure associated with a desire to defecate on the partner or to be defected on.
  • Urophilia- the sexual pleasure associated with the desire to urinate on a partner or to be urinated on.
  • Hypoxyphilia- is the desire to achieve an altered state of consciousness secondary to hypoxia while experiencing orgasm. They may use volatile nitrite or nitrous oxide to produce hypoxia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient was posted for unilateral mastectomy for breast carcinoma. Halothane was used as the inhalational agent. Intraoperatively she develops fever and tachycardia. On physical examination, rigidity was noted in the masseter muscle. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. The drug of choice for the condition is dantrolene.

Dantrolene is a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on the RyR1 (ryanodine receptor) calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles and inhibits calcium-induced calcium release. This results in the uncoupling of membrane depolarization and muscle contraction, thus inhibiting muscle contraction.

Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic condition in which mutated RyR1 receptors are present in the skeletal muscles. In the presence of certain triggers, this mutated RyR1 causes severe dysfunction in the RyR1 channels. This leads to the accumulation of calcium ions in the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction, rigidity, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal CO2.

Drugs triggering malignant hyperthermia:

  • Succinylcholine
  • Halothane
  • Isoflurane
  • Sevoflurane

Susceptible patients:

  • Patients with a positive family history. It can be inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.
  • Patients with congenital myopathies.

Treatment: 

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive treatment with rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia should be given

Other options:

Options A and C: Succinylcholine and isoflurane are known to cause malignant hyperthermia, and hence cannot be used for the management.

Option D: Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant.

questions.text: The skull findings in the given child below are typically seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The child in the given picture has Craniotabes (soft skull) and frontal bossing (also shown below) which are clinical features of rickets seen in vitamin D deficiency.

Clinical Features of Rickets:

General:

  • Failure to thrive
  • Listlessness
  • Protruding abdomen
  • Muscle weakness (especially proximal)
  • Fractures

Head:

  • Craniotabes
  • Frontal bossing
  • Delayed fontanel closure
  • Delayed dentition
  • Craniosynostosis

Chest:

  • Rachitic rosary
  • Harrison groove
  • Respiratory infections and atelectasis

Back:

  • Scoliosis, kyphosis, lordosis

Extremities:

  • Enlargement of wrists and ankles
  • Valgus or varus deformities
  • Windswept deformity
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia
  • Coxa vara

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is brought to the pediatric cardiology clinic due to concerns about possible congenital heart disease. The child's parents report episodes of fatigue and shortness of breath during physical activities. On examination, the pediatrician notes a heart murmur and decides to assess the child using Nada's Criteria. Which of the following is included in Nada's Minor Criteria?
questions.solution:
Nada's Minor Criteria includes an abnormal second heart sound.

Nada’s criteria is used to diagnose congenital heart disease in children. The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.

Major criteria  Minor criteria
Systolic murmur  grade 3 or more Systolic murmur < grade 3
Any diastolic murmur Abnormal second sound (S2)
Cyanosis Abnormal ECG
Congestive cardiac failure

Abnormal chest X-ray findings
 

Abnormal BP

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is scheduled for a cesarean section. The anesthesiologist discusses the anaesthesia options with her, including epidural anaesthesia. The patient expresses interest in understanding how epidural anaesthesia works. Which of the following describes the location where the local anaesthetic is administered during epidural anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Epidural anesthesia involves local anesthetic administration between the dura and ligamentum flavum.

Subdural injection (seen in a failed spinal anesthesia) is between dura and arachnoid.

Spinal anesthesia (subarachnoid block, intrathecal block) involves local anesthetic administration between the pia and arachnoid mater.

In spinal anesthesia, the local anesthetic is injected into CSF, which bathes the nerve root. Hence, a relatively small dose and volume of local anesthetic is sufficient to achieve dense sensory and motor blockade.

questions.text: A 55-year old man presents with an inability to hold his head up, progressive atrophy and weakness of his hands and forearms over the past few months. On examination, he is found to have spasticity of the legs and brisk jaw jerk. What is the drug that can be given to improve his survival and slow down the progression of this disease?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with both upper motor and lower motor lesions is suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Riluzole is the drug that can be given to improve his survival and slow down the progression of this disease.

Riluzole is absorbed orally and is highly protein-bound. It works by reducing excitotoxicity by blocking voltage-dependent sodium channels and by diminishing glutamate release. Riluzole extended the survival of ALS patients by 2-3 months.

questions.text: In a live donor kidney transplantation, the donor's renal artery should be anastomosed with which of the following?

choices.text: End-to-end anastomosis with internal iliac artery
End-to-side anastomosis with internal iliac artery
End-to-end anastomosis with external iliac artery
End-to-side anastomosis with external iliac artery

questions.solution:
In a live donor kidney transplantation, the donor's renal artery is end-to-end anastomosed with the recipient's internal iliac artery.

In the renal transplant, the renal vessels are anastomosed as follows:

  Living donor Cadaveric donor
Anastomosis End-to-end End-to-side
Recipient artery Internal iliac artery External iliac artery
Recipient vein External iliac vein External iliac vein

The below image shows the different types of anastomosis in kidney transplantation from live and deceased donors.

The usual site for kidney transplantation is the iliac fossa in the retroperitoneal position, making it a heterotopic type of transplantation. The diseased kidney is left in situ.

The optimal cold storage time for the kidney is 18 hours, and the maximum safe cold storage time for the kidney is 36 hours.

Optimal and maximum safe cold storage time for various organs are as follows:

Organs Optimal time (hours) Maximum time (hours)
1) Kidney <18 <36
2) Liver <12 <18
3) Pancreas <10 <18
4) Small intestine <4 <6
5) Heart <3 <6
6) Lungs <3 <8

Note: 

In orthotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed in its normal anatomical site. However, in heterotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed at a site different from its normal anatomical site.

questions.text: A young patient comes to the emergency with pain in the right leg after falling from a height. The radiological image shows a physeal injury fracture extending to epiphysis was present. What is the type of Salter-Harris physeal injury mentioned above?
questions.solution:
The type of Salter-Harris injury mentioned above is type III injury.

Type II fracture is an intraarticular fracture. In a type III Salter harris fracture, the fracture splits the epiphysis and divides transversely to the other side through the hypertrophic layer of the physis. This damages the growth plate and results in growth disturbance.

The fracture lower end of the tibia is an example of a Salter-Harris type 3 fracture.

Salter-Harris type III fracture needs an accurate reduction to restore the joint surface.

Salter-Harris classified epiphyseal injuries into 5 types as mentioned below.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and jaundice. Imaging studies reveal an opacity in the liver, and the patient is diagnosed with pyogenic liver abscess. During the discussion with the medical team, the patient asks about the characteristics of the pus within the abscess. Which of the following statements is NOT true?

choices.text: Anchovy sauce pus is seen within the abscess.
Ascending infection from the biliary tract is the most common route of spread.
Escherichia coli and Klebsiella species are the most common organisms involved.
It usually involves the right lobe.

questions.solution:
Anchovy sauce pus is a characteristic feature of amoebic liver abscess. It is not seen in pyogenic liver abscess.

Pyogenic liver abscess is a polymicrobial infection seen more commonly in the elderly and immunocompromised. It has the following features:

Route of spread:

  • Ascending infection from the biliary tree (ascending suppurative cholangitis): most common route of spread.
    • The cause of biliary obstruction in Asians is intrahepatic stones and cholangitis; in Western populations, it is malignancy. Other causes of biliary obstruction are Caroli disease, biliary ascariasis, and biliary tract surgery.
  • Portal vein (2nd most common): Pylephlebitis secondary to diverticulitis, appendicitis, pancreatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, pelvic inflammatory disease, perforated viscus, and omphalitis in the newborn.
  • Hepatic artery: Systemic infection 
  • Direct extension: Suppurative chole­cystitis, subphrenic abscess, perinephric abscess
  • Perfora­tion of the bowel directly into the liver

Organism:

  • Most common in Western countries: Escherichia coli
  • Most common in Asian countries: Klebsiella pneumoniae
  • Most common in children suffering from the chronic granulomatous disease: Staphylococcus
  • Most common in gas-forming abscess: Klebsiella

Site:

Right lobe (75%) > left lobe (20%) > caudate lobe (5%). Right lobe predilection might be due to preferential laminar blood flow.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient with recurrent urinary tract infections, the following urographic finding was observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole due to an obstructed (and unopacified) upper pole. This is called the drooping lily sign and is observed in patients with a duplicated collecting system. 

This condition is characterized by an incomplete fusion of upper and lower pole moieties resulting in a variety of complete or incomplete duplications of the collecting system.

Duplex collecting systems may also be complicated by vesicoureteric reflux, obstruction, or ureterocoele.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with constant dribbling of urine. She has a history of prolonged labor in her previous pregnancy. She feels uncomfortable because her underwear is constantly wet.  Examination reveals excoriation of the genital area. Methylene blue - 3 swab test reveals staining of the uppermost swab. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is vesicovaginal fistula. 

Vesicovaginal fistula is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract. 

Vesicovaginal fistulae occur mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine. The presence of urine in the undergarments is uncomfortable and leads to pruritus and excoriation of the genital area. 

Per speculum examination must be performed to determine the extent of local tissue involvement and the number of fistulas. 

Investigations to be performed include

  • Urine culture and treatment of infection if required
  • Ultrasound of the kidney, ureter, and bladder
  • Intravenous pyelography
  • Cystoscopy with indigo carmine excretion test
  • Ureteric catheterization
  • Methylene blue - 3 swab test if the fistula is small. Here, methylene blue is injected into the bladder via the catheter, and three sterile swabs are placed into the vaginal cavity.  
    • If the uppermost swab is stained, it is suggestive of a vesicovaginal fistula
    • If the lowermost swab is stained, it is suggestive of a fistula in the urethra(Urethrovaginal fistula)
    • If the swabs do not get stained but get wet with urine then the fistula is from the ureter.

Vesicovaginal fistula is treated surgically. It can be attempted after 3 months to allow the inflammation to subside and clear the infection. After this, the Latzko procedure can be performed. Here, the vaginal epithelium around the fistula is removed and the edges are approximated. The Chassar Moir technique can also be attempted. Here, the vagina and bladder are separated and sutured to two layers taking care to avoid tension and overlapping suture lines. 

Other options: 

Option A - Vesicouterine fistula is very rare and generally occurs after operative surgeries on the uterus. The patient is continent but has cyclical hematuria as the menstrual blood and urine mix. 

Option B - Ureteric fistula occur when there is direct injury to the ureter in the pelvis during gynecological procedures. In these cases, the women leak urine into the peritoneal cavity leading to abdominal symptoms of nausea, vomiting, distension, and ileus. 

Option D - Urethrovaginal fistula occurs when there's damage during obstetric surgeries. Here, the patient would be normally continent and dry but has dribbling urine from the vagina during or after micturition.

questions.text: A couple presents to you after unprotected sexual intercourse and asks for an emergency contraceptive. All of the following are mechanisms by which emergency contraceptives act, except?

choices.text: Preventing the implantation of the fertilized egg

questions.solution:
Emergency contraception has no role in the interruption of early pregnancy, once conceived. They are not abortifacients.

Emergency contraceptives are used to prevent pregnancy, after unprotected intercourse. They are interceptives. Their main action is to make the endometrium unsuitable for implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation, and prevent fertilization of the egg by sperms.

questions.text: A true statement regarding the pre-anesthetic consideration for use of warfarin in a 76-year-old woman with non-valvular atrial fibrillation and 3-month-old stroke, posted for hip replacement under neuraxial block is_____.

choices.text: Stop warfarin 4-5 days preoperatively and check INR
Stop warfarin 4-5 days preoperatively and continue LMWH till a day before surgery
Stop warfarin on the day of surgery

questions.solution:
Since the patient has increased thromboembolic risk (AF, stroke), warfarin is stopped 4-5 days pre-operatively and LMWH is bridged till the day before(24 hours) surgery. Decisions to use bridging therapy with unfractionated heparin (UFH) or LMWH must be individualized depending on thromboembolic risk, bleeding risk and timing of anticoagulant interruption.

In patients at high risk for thrombosis (e.g., those with certain mechanical heart valve implants or with atrial fibrillation and a prior thromboembolic stroke), warfarin should be stopped and replaced by UFH or LMWH to minimize the risk. 

Patients at lower risk for thrombosis may have warfarin discontinued 4-5 days preoperatively and then reinitiated after successful surgery.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown by the arrow.
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the common hepatic duct.

ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography. A side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla. It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree. It can be both therapeutic and diagnostic.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is performed using a side-viewing fibreoptic duodenoscope.

The ampulla of Vater is intubated, and contrast is injected into the biliary and pancreatic ducts to display the anatomy radiologically.

The most common significant complication is acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presented with unilateral proptosis. CT scan of the orbit shows poorly defined mass with homogenous density with adjacent bony destruction. Histopathology is shown below. The immunohistochemistry of the cells was Desmin positive. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and histopathology are suggestive of Rhabdomyosarcoma.

Rhabdomyosarcomas are the common soft tissue sarcomas of childhood and adolescence that may occur at virtually any anatomic site but are usually found in the head and neck (25%), genitourinary tract (24%), extremities (19%), and orbit (9%). Retroperitoneum and other sites account for the remainder of primary sites.

It is classified into three subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, and pleomorphic.

Type Histopathology
Embryonal 

Tumour consists of sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma.

 Sarcoma botryoid is a variant that occurs in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile, bladder, and vagina.
Alveolar  Tumour consists of a network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli. 
Pleomorphic Tumour consists of large, sometimes multinucleated, bizarre eosinophilic tumour cells.


Clinically, the tumour is usually aggressive, with unilateral proptosis when the orbit is involved. Swelling and redness of the overlying skin, diplopia may be present.


In immunohistochemistry, they are positive for 

  • Desmin 
  • Myoglobin
  • Myogenin
  • MyoD1
  • Vimentin.

Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults.


Rhabdomyosarcoma shows a strong tendency for local invasion, local recurrence, and hematogenous and lymphatic metastases.

Decision-making for management is based on histopathologic confirmation as well as the staging of orbital RMS, which includes imaging (MRI of primary tumour, chest-CT, Tc bone scan), pathology, and work-up for metastases(bone marrow biopsy)

  • Group I: Localized disease, completely resected (excisional biopsy).
  • Group II: Microscopic disease remaining after biopsy.
  • Group III: Gross residual disease remaining after biopsy.
  • Group IV: Distant metastasis present at onset.

The current European pediatric Soft tissue sarcoma Study Group (EpSSG) protocol:

  • Group I: Chemotherapy consisting of Vincristine, Actinomycin D.
  • Groups II and III: Chemotherapy (Vincristine +Actinomycin D) +/- Ifosfamide +/- radiotherapy
  • Group IV: Intensified chemotherapy regimen (Irinotecan+Vincristine+Actinomycin D) and doxorubicin) followed by one year of maintenance chemotherapy and radiotherapy


The below image shows histopathology of Orbital Rhabdomyosarcoma

questions.text:
Arrange the following stages of xerophthalmia in the correct order of progression, according to WHO grading.

1. Conjunctival xerosis

2. Keratomalacia

3. Corneal xerosis

4. Corneal scar

5. Bitot's spot
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of stages of xerophthalmia is 1 - 5 - 3 - 2 - 4.

Xerophthalmia is a term used to cover all ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency. According to WHO grading, the order of progression is as follows:

  • XN: Night blindness
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis
  • X1B: Bitot's spot
  • X2: Corneal xerosis
  • X3A: Keratomalacia affecting less than 1/3rd of the corneal surface
  • X3B: Keratomalacia affecting greater than 1/3rd of the corneal surface
  • XS: Corneal scar
  • XF: Xerophthalmic fundus

Treatment includes local ocular therapy, vitamin A therapy, and treatment of underlying general disease.

Vitamin A therapy is given as:

  • All patients who are older than 1 year (except the reproductive age group of women) should be given 200,000 lU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU intramuscularly immediately on diagnosis, and then repeated the following day and 4 weeks later.
  • Children who weigh less than 8kg or are under the age of 1 year should be treated with half the dose (100,000IU).
  • In women of the reproductive age group, the stages of XN to X1B are treated with 10,000 IU daily for 2 weeks. In stages of corneal xerophthalmia (X3 and above), a full dose of 200,000 IU is given orally.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU in 9 doses given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5 years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-11 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

questions.text: The following X-rays depicts_______?
questions.solution:
The given x ray depicts Melorheostosis.

Melorheostosis: It is also known as Leri's Disease. It is a rare mesenchymal dysplasia manifesting as regions of sclerosis of cortices with a characteristic dripping wax appearance or flowing candle wax appearance. The presentation is usually monostotic and unilateral. Symptoms include pain, deformity, skin and circulation problems and contractures.

Osteopoikilosis is a benign autosomal dominant sclerosing bone dysplasia with multiple bone islands in a peri-articular distribution in tubular bones, pelvis and scapulae. They are typically bilateral and symmetrical.

Osteopathia striata, is a rare, benign dysplasia of bone with radiographically prominent vertical striations involving the epiphysis and metaphysis of tubular bones. It is typically asymptomatic, although there can be associated joint discomfort.

Related Pearl: Classical radiological appearance of bone tumors

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a female condom. It consists of a pouch made of polyurethane which is 17 cm in length with flexible ring at each end. The inner ring at the closed end is smaller than the outer ring.

The inner ring is inserted at the apex of the vagina and the outer ring remains outside. It covers the cervix, entire vagina, and external genitalia. Hence, it provides protection against HIV and STDs. It has a failure rate of 5–15 per 100 woman-years, which is higher than that of a male condom.

questions.text: An oncologist is evaluating an elderly woman with breast cancer for possible bony metastases. Given the patient's clinical presentation and history, the oncologist decides to order a bone scan for further assessment. Which of the following radioactive isotopes is typically used for bone scans in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Technetium tagged to various substrates is used for bone scans.

The patient is injected with a small amount of radioactive material such as 600 MBq of technetium-99m-MDP and scanned with a gamma camera, a device sensitive to the radiation emitted by the injected material. MDP (methyl diphosphonate) adsorbs into the hydroxyapatite crystals and accumulates in the areas of active bone formation. 

Given below is a bone scan demonstrating bony metastasis in the pelvis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common method of diagnostic investigation in patients suspected to have hypernephroma?
questions.solution:
The most common method of diagnostic investigation in hypernephroma or renal cell carcinoma is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. Characteristic features of RCC on CT scan include:

  • Enhancement of the lesion after injection of IV contrast
  • Thickened irregular walls
  • Thickened or enhanced septa within the mass or multilocular mass

CT scan has replaced IVP and ultrasound as the radiological modality of choice to evaluate renal masses.

MRI can be performed for diagnosing poorly characterized renal masses on CT or if a CT scan is contraindicated (in case of allergy to IV contrast). It also helps in defining tumor extension into the renal vein or IVC. 

The below image shows a cystic tumor involving the left kidney suggestive of renal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Fertilized ovum implants in the uterine cavity by ______
questions.solution:
Fertilized ovum implants in the uterine cavity by 6–10 days.

Implantation involves: 

  •  Apposition: Initial contact of the blastocyst to the uterine wall
  •  Adhesion: Increased physical contact between the blastocyst and uterine epithelium
  •  Invasion: Penetration and invasion of syncytiotrophoblast and cytotrophoblasts into the endometrium

 

Successful implantation requires receptive endometrium primed with estrogen and progesterone released by corpus luteum.

questions.text: Which of the following was launched to ensure complete immunization of children?
questions.solution:
Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush, to achieve the same goal by December 2018. 

Intensified Mission Indradhanush includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month).

The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

questions.text: A 45 -year-old presented with severe pain in the right leg below the knee. He had a history of restricted ambulation and prolonged bed rest due to his severe back pain. He has no other comorbidities or history of smoking. On examination of his right calf, discoloration and significantly increased girth are noted and are shown below. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Deep vein thrombosis due to immobilization and venous stasis is the most likely cause.

Deep Vein Thrombosis:

DVT most commonly occurs in the calf veins and less often in the proximal veins of the thigh and pelvis. Deep vein thrombosis is caused due to 3 broad categories of risk factors (Virchow's triad):

  • Hemodynamic changes (stasis or turbulence)
  • Hypercoagulability 
  • Endothelial injury/dysfunction

Causes

  • Postoperative thrombosis: (Most common cause)
    • Following childbirth
    • Trauma- to leg, ankle, thigh, pelvis
    • Muscular violence
    • Immobility – Bed-ridden patients, individuals on long-duration air or bus travel (Traveller’s thrombosis).
    • Debilitating illness, obesity, immobility, bed rest, pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives, estrogens.

Sites

  1. Pelvic veins—common
  2. Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (Common on the left side).

Features of DVT

  • Fever-commonest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s, or Neuhof’s signs
  • Inverted champagne bottle sign
  • Commonly it is asymptomatic
  • Features of pulmonary embolism

Treatment

  • Rest, the elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with
  • crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight
  • heparin, warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation  

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the ER with complaints of acute onset nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea. She gives a history of consumption of street food earlier the same day. Which of the following organisms is likely to be responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of acute onset gastroenteritis. Since the symptoms appeared shortly after ingestion, they are caused due to preformed toxins. From the given options, Staphylococcus aureus is associated with preformed toxins.

The aetiology of gastroenteritis is as follows :

1. Preformed toxin:

  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Bacillus cereus
  • Clostridium perfringens 

2. Toxin forming: 

  • Vibrio cholerae
  • Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)

3. Invasive:

  • Shigella
  • Salmonella
  • Yersinia
  • Campylobacter

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with hyperpigmented macules on her upper lip, malar regions, forehead, chin, and mandible, which worsen after sun exposure. Based on this clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 30-year-old woman showing hyperpigmented macules on the upper lip, malar regions, forehead, chin, and mandible region is suggestive of melasma.

Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis and is manifested by hyperpigmented macules on the face which become more pronounced after sun exposure. Hyper-melanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, the forehead,  chin and the mandible region. It is more common in women (90%) and in ages between 20-40 years. Melasma is frequently seen in women on oral contraceptives. Melasma is more chronic and requires treatment with depigmenting agents like hydroquinone (reduces tyrosinase activity), kojic acid (tyrosinase inhibitor), chemical peels and Kligman's triple combination- topical hydroquinone + tretinoin + corticosteroid compound cream (First line)

Other Options:

Option A: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus: A well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

Option C: The same facial melanosis in pregnant women is called Chloasma or mask of pregnancy. Only the terms used differ. Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Chloasma usually resolves after pregnancy.

Option D: Rosacea is seen at the convexities of the face and presents as an erythemato-telangiectatic type over the cheeks.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for the past 4 months. However, the disease is still progressing. What would be your recommendation for the further management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.solution:
For further management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with worsening disease activity, the preferred therapy is a step-up to oral triple therapy with methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine. The addition of leflunomide or a biological (anti - TNF) to methotrexate is another alternative.

Ideally, the approach to a patient with early RA is aggressive. Methotrexate is always the first DMARD that the patient is started on, and if an adequate response is not observed within 3-6 months, a step up in therapy is made by adding on drugs.

For assessment of progression, composite indices like Disease Activity Score - 28 (DAS-28) can used.

Other options:

Option A: Changing the route of administration of methotrexate from oral to parenteral is not a part of step up 

Option C: Priority is given to minimising the duration the patient is on steroids.

Option D: Anti -TNF agents (adalimumab, etanercept) are not recommended as a monotherapy, and are reserved for treatment in combination with DMARDs. This is due to the fact that the efficacy of monotherapy is lesser than that of DMARDs, and the adverse effects include increased risk of serious infections, re-activation of latent TB and opportunistic fungal infections. They are reserved for cases where there is a lack of response with the first line agents.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post-menopausal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a mass with feeding vessel as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Visualisation of a feeding vessel on ultrasonography is characteristic of an endometrial polyp.

Ultrasonography shows endometrial polyps, which are homogeneous, isoechoic to and continuous with the endometrium and preserve the endomyometrial interface. They may be centrally cystic, corresponding to dilated, fluid-filled glands. Colour Doppler usually reveals a characteristic feeding vessel.

 Benign endometrial polyps commonly occur at all ages, with their greatest prevalence after age 50. They are a common cause of postmenopausal bleeding.

questions.text: Mala N contains ____
questions.solution:
Mala N contains LNG and ethinyl estradiol.

Combined Oral Pills (OC):

Combined oral pills contain a mixture of ethinyl estradiol (EE2) in a dose of 20-30 mcg and an orally active progestogen.

Mala-D and Mala-N both contain 0.15 mg LNG and 0.03mg ethinyl estradiol.

The only difference being that Mala-D is available at a price of Rs 3/- per packet whereas Mala-N is supplied free of cost through all PHC's, urban family welfare centers etc.

  • The tablets are taken starting on the second day of the cycle for 21 days (now started on 1st day). A new course of tablets should be commenced 7 days after the cessation of the previous course. They should be taken at a bedtime of the day, preferably after a meal.
  • The combined oral pill suppresses pituitary hormones, FSH and LH peak and through their suppression prevents ovulation. At the same time, progestogen causes atrophic changes in the endometrium and prevents nidation. Progestogen also acts on the cervical mucus making it thick and tenacious and impenetrable by sperms.
  • It also increases the tubal motility, so the fertilized egg reaches the uterine cavity before the endometrium is receptive for implantation.

Pregnancy rate is 0.3% with perfect use and 8% with typical use of the combined oral pill.

According to Park, 24th edition, the cost of Mala-D is Rs.3. While some other websites give it as Rs.5. The reference of Park is taken into consideration.

questions.text: An infant born at 30 weeks of gestation presents with respiratory grunting. An X-ray is obtained, and the findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the X-ray findings?
questions.solution:
Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, affects newborns due to the decreased production and secretion of the lung surfactant. Surfactant deficiency leads to an increase in the surface tension over the alveoli, causing the alveoli to collapse easily during expiration. 

Deficiency of surfactant ---> Alveolar collapse ---> Inadequate oxygenation ---> Increased work of breathing ---> Hypoxemia and acidosis ---> Pulmonary vasoconstriction ---> Right to left shunting ---> Worsening hypoxemia and respiratory failure.

The Chest X-ray shows (as seen above):

  • Fine reticulogranular pattern
  • Bilateral diffuse ground glass opacities
  • Air bronchograms

White-out lung is seen in severe disease.

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have renal tubular acidosis. His lab parameters show elevated potassium levels and metabolic acidosis. Identify the correct pair describing the diagnosis from the following options.

choices.text: Renal tubular acidosis 2 - impaired HCO3- reabsorption
Renal tubular acidosis 1 - impaired H+ secretion

questions.solution:
Renal tubular acidosis 4 - hypoaldosteronism is the correct pair that explains the diagnosis of the given patient.

RTA 4 (hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis) is associated with aldosterone deficiency or resistance, leading to impaired potassium excretion, leading to hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis.

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which there is impaired tubular transport of H+ and/or HCO3- despite relatively well-preserved renal function. There are 4 types:

  • Type I - impaired H+ secretion (distal), leading to decreased HCO3- production
  • Type II - impaired HCO3- reabsorption (proximal)
  • Type III - carbonic anhydrase deficiency causing defects in the transport of both H+ and HCO3- (mixed)
  • Type IV - hypoaldosteronism (hyperkalemic)

The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal.

Other options:

Option B: RTA 2 (Proximal Renal Tubular Acidosis): This condition involves impaired bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubules, leading to metabolic acidosis. Hypokalemia can occur due to urinary losses of potassium.

Option C: RTA 4 causes features of hypoaldosteronism and not hyperaldosteronism. So, this option is incorrect.

Option D: RTA 1 (Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis): This condition is characterized by impaired acid secretion in the distal renal tubules, leading to metabolic acidosis. Hypokalemia can occur due to the compensatory secretion of potassium to maintain electroneutrality.
