questions.text: As a medical officer, you are asked to educate the students in your community about following a healthy lifestyle from a very young age. Also, lifestyle modifications and ill effects of alcohol and drugs are planned to be taught to the students. What level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Educating the students about following a healthy lifestyle and the ill effects of alcohol and drugs falls under the primordial level of prevention. 

The primordial level of prevention involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared.

Primordial prevention consists of risk factor reduction targeted towards an entire population through a focus on social and environmental conditions. Measures taken for this level of prevention are typically promoted through laws and national policies. The main intervention in primordial prevention is individual and mass education.

Examples of the concerns addressed at this level include adult health problems, like obesity and hypertension, that have an early onset due to lifestyle factors, like smoking, poor eating patterns, and lack of physical exercise; preventive measures are directed at discouraging these practices from early childhood.

Other options:

Option A: Secondary prevention includes early disease detection and targets healthy-looking individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. Secondary prevention is defined as an intervention that halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.

Option C: Tertiary prevention includes all rehabilitation measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities and to minimize suffering caused by any stage of the disease. This also promotes the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions. Tertiary prevention extends the concepts of prevention by rehabilitation.

Option D: Primary prevention is defined as an action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Primary prevention is obtained by measures promoting general health and well-being and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures. This helps in the modification of risk factors of a disease.

questions.text: A 14-year-old adolescent presents to the orthopaedic clinic with complaints of persistent bone pain in the right leg, especially at night. On examination, there is localized tenderness over the midshaft of the right femur, and the affected limb appears slightly swollen. An X-ray of the right femur shows an onion peel appearance on the diaphysis of the bone. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The characteristic X-ray appearance of the Onion peel type of periosteal reaction is seen in Ewing’s sarcoma. The other characteristic x-ray appearances are seen in the following conditions:

  • Sunburst (sunray) appearance - Osteosarcoma (Option A)
  • Soap bubble appearance - Giant cell tumor (Option C)
  • Multiple punched-out lesions - Multiple myeloma (Option D)

Sunray appearance or Codman triangle is commonly seen in Osteosarcoma but can also be seen in Ewing’s sarcoma.

Giant cell tumor shows soap bubble Appearance.

Pathognomonic sign of Unicameral bone cyst on radiograph is Fallen fragment sign.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with frequently changing bowel habits. He noticed blood in the stools which were not associated with pain. There was no history of weight loss. Barium enema shows multiple outpouchings in the ascending, transverse, and descending colon resembling a saw-tooth.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is colonic diverticulosis.

The above clinical scenario with the barium enema image is suggestive of colonic diverticulosis. The barium enema shows multiple outpouchings in the ascending, transverse, and descending colon resembling a saw-tooth, indicating diverticulosis.  

Diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. Colonic diverticulosis is more common among the age group of more than 50 years. Colonic diverticulosis is primarily false diverticula as only the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated. Due to the high intraluminal pressure, they are referred to as the pulsion type of diverticula. A low fibre diet results in smaller stool volume that increases intraluminal pressure for propulsion. The higher pressures get directed to the colonic wall resulting in pulsion diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common location.

The majority of the patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with abdominal cramps, altered bowel habits, and painless rectal bleeding. Diverticulosis can present with complications like:

  • Diverticulitis
  • Abscess
  • Peritonitis
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Hemorrhage 
  • Fistula formation

Diagnosis:

The diagnosis is confirmed by a colonoscopy or an X-ray barium enema. Barium enema radiograph shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth. In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

The saw-tooth appearence is seen below:

 

Treatment:

A high fibre diet reduces the incidence of diverticulosis. Antispasmodics can be prescribed to reduce intestinal spasms. Most cases of bleeding are self-limiting. If persistent bleeding is present, surgical, endoscopic or radiological interventions can be done to reduce the bleeding.

Other options:

Option B- Carcinoma colon shows apple-core sign on barium enema as shown below. 

 

Option C- Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows the string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below.

 

Option D- Intussusception shows the coiled-spring appearance on barium enema as shown below.

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate is being evaluated for failure to thrive, excessive vomiting, abdominal distention, and steatorrhea.  Abdominal CT reveals hepatosplenomegaly and calcified adrenals bilaterally. Further investigation reveals a deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid lipase (LAL). Which of the following is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, intractable vomiting, steatorrhea, and bilateral adrenal calcification points towards a probable diagnosis of Wolman disease.

Wolman disease is a rare disorder that results from a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL). This leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in most of the visceral organs, leading to organomegaly as in this case. Patients present in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.

LAL deficiency can present in two forms- Wolman disease and cholesterol ester storage disease. Cholesterol ester storage disease is less severe and usually presents late in adulthood, whereas Wolman disease presents within the first few weeks of life and results in death within the first 6 months of life. 

Wolman disease can be diagnosed by measuring LAL activity in peripheral leukocytes or cultured skin fibroblasts. Treatment is with a recombinant form of LAL. Those treated have been seen to survive beyond one year of age.

Other options-

Option (A): Krabbe disease is also a fatal disease of early infancy but it occurs due to a deficiency in the enzyme galactocerebrosidase and hence, the accumulation of galactosylceramide in the white matter of the brain.

Option (B): Farber disease results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme acid ceramidase. Thus, ceramide accumulates in various tissues, especially the joints. Symptoms include painful joint swelling and nodule formation, resembling rheumatoid arthritis within the first year of life.

Option (D): Gaucher disease is one of the most common lysosomal storage disorders. It occurs due to a deficiency of acid β-glucosidase. It presents most commonly with organomegaly, bone pain, and pathological fractures. It is most prevalent among Ashkenazi Jews.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with shortness of breath. His post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC < 0.7 and FEV1 is 55%. He walks slower than his peers due to his breathlessness. He’s had two hospital admissions this year. Under what category would he be classified based on GOLD criteria?

A patient showing FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted is categorized as moderate COPD.
Two hospital admissions and MRC grade 2 dyspnoea (stops for breath when walking on level) would be Group D

World COPD Day will take place annually on 18 November. The theme for 2020 will be “Living Well with COPD - Everybody, Everywhere". This year's aim is to send a positive message to both patients and providers that although COPD does not have a cure, there are many ways to actively live well.

questions.text: A young woman presented with a rash as shown in the image below. She also complains of recurrent oral ulcers and pain in multiple joints. Investigations revealed antibodies to double-stranded DNA. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A young woman with a butterfly-shaped malar rash, a history of recurrent oral ulcers, pain in multiple joints, and antibodies to double-stranded DNA is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

SLE is an autoimmune disorder that results in damage to multiple organs and organ systems in the body most commonly seen in women of reproductive age.  

Clinical and immunological manifestations of SLE:

  1. Skin
    • acute, subacute cutaneous manifestations (photosensitivity, malar or maculopapular rash)
    • chronic cutaneous manifestations (discoid lupus, panniculitis, lichen planus-like) 
  2. Oral or nasal ulcers
  3. Non-scarring alopecia
  4. Synovitis involving ≥2 joints
  5. Serositis (pleurisy, pericarditis)
  6. Renal: 
    • Protein/Creatinine ratio >0.5
    • RBC casts
  7. Neurologic: seizures, psychosis, myelitis, neuropathy, confusional state
  8. Hemolytic anemia
  9. Leukopenia
  10. Thrombocytopenia
  11. Immunological manifestations
    • Antinuclear antibodies >reference value (positive in >98% patients)
    • Anti-dsDNA >reference value (specific)
    • Anti-Smith antibody (specific)
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (lupus anticoagulant, false-positive rapid plasma reagin)
    • Low serum complement

To diagnose SLE, at least 4 out of 11 of the above criteria must be positive. However, if a renal biopsy is suggestive of lupus nephritis and lupus autoantibodies are positive then four criteria are not required. 

Other options: 

Option A: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy that presents with symmetrical weakness in the proximal muscles. Classical dermatological manifestations include- gottron's papules (raised erythematous rash) on the knuckles, and elbows, a shawl sign on the back, and the heliotrope rash over the eyelids (erythematous discoloration with periorbital edema). Laboratory findings include elevated creatinine kinase levels and autoantibodies like anti-Mi2.

Option B: Behcet's disease is a multisystem disorder that requires recurrent oral ulceration plus two of the following criteria for a definitive diagnosis -

  • Recurrent genital ulceration
  • Ocular lesions
  • Skin lesions 
  • Positive pathergy test

Laboratory findings are usually non-specific signs of inflammation and elevated C-reactive protein levels.

Option C: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease that results in damage to the articular cartilage. It can also have a broad range of extra-articular manifestations. The autoantibodies seen in this disease are anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies and rheumatoid factor.

Anti-Ro/SSA, Anti-La/SSB Sjögren’s syndrome
Anti-Scl-70 (anti-DNA topoisomerase) Diffuse scleroderma
Anticentromere CREST syndrome
Anti-SRP, Anti-Mi-2, Anti-Jo-1 Polymyositis, Dermatomyositis
p-ANCA/MPO Churg Strauss syndrome
c-ANCA Wegener (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)

questions.text: A 29-year-old male is admitted with a history of polytrauma. He is hemodynamically unstable. After initial resuscitation, the surgeon performs a FAST (Focused assessment with sonography in trauma) examination. Which area will not be visualized on FAST?
questions.solution:
Left lower quadrant is not assessed in FAST examination.

FAST is a rapid diagnostic examination that uses USG to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries- hemoperitoneum and hemopericardium. It is performed within 2­-4 minutes. 

Five regions may be scanned :

  • Subxiphoid transverse view: Assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries.
  • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: Assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison's pouch.
  • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: Assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury.
  • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: Assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas.

An "extended FAST or eFAST" scan: Assess left and right thoracic views, in addition to the FAST assessed regions, to look for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. And she is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain and on examination the right adnexal mass was palpable, non tender. On USG examination she has a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary. Which is the next step

choices.text: Reassure and advise regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualise the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.solution:
Doing a CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for Post-menopausal Ovarian cyst.

Initial steps in management include the following:

  • Estimate CA – 125 level
  • USG
  • Calculating Risk of Malignancy index
    • RMI = U x  M  x  Ca-125
    • U – Ultrasound score
    • M – Menopausal status
    • Ca 125 – Serum levels

Option B - CT scan is not recommended in initial evaluation.

Option C - Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size > 5 cm or RMI > 200.

questions.text: While performing an inguinal hernia repair in a 3-year-old boy, you notice Meckel’s diverticulum as the content of the hernial sac. What is this hernia called?
questions.solution:
Meckel’s diverticulum found in inguinal or femoral hernial sacs is known as Littre's hernia. It can cause intestinal obstruction.

Option A: Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option B: Narath’s hernia is seen in patients with congenital dislocation of the hip. It is a femoral hernia seen behind the femoral vessels.

Option C: Cloquet’s hernia is a type of femoral hernia where the sac lies under the pectineus fascia.

questions.text: On evaluating the pulse of an elderly patient, the consultant noticed 'Water-hammer pulse'. It is a characteristic feature of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Water-hammer pulse (Corrigan’s pulse) is a characteristic feature of aortic regurgitation among the given options.

It is also seen in

  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Persistent ductus arteriosus
  • Arteriovenous fistula
  • Rupture of sinus of Valsalva

It is characterized by a rapid upstroke and a rapid downstroke. The rapid downstroke is due to the rapid run-off of blood into

  • the cavity of the left ventricle in AR
  • the pulmonary artery in PDA 
  • the veins in the case of AV fistula

 The rapid upstroke is due to increased stroke volume secondary to the hyperdynamic state.

Other options:

  • Aortic stenosis presents with pulsus parvus et tardus. It is seen as a low-amplitude pulse that rises slowly and has a late peak.
  • HOCM presents with a bisferiens pulse. It is seen with a rapid upstroke to the first peak and a slower rise to the second peak.

Signs in aortic regurgitation:

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the urology clinic for evaluation of a horseshoe kidney, which was incidentally discovered on imaging. He is concerned about potential complications and treatment options for his condition. Which of the following statements regarding this patient's condition is FALSE?

choices.text: Adrenal glands are  normal  in position

questions.solution:
Heminephrectomy is not indicated in horseshoe kidney because it can result in the devascularisation of the lower ends of both the kidneys. 

Horseshoe kidney

  • 2:1 male:female ratio
  • Associated with sacral agenesis and Turner syndrome
  • Fused portion lies adjacent to the L3 or L4 vertebra just below the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery. Ascent of the fused kidneys is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery.
  • Increase in urinary stasis, infection, and nephrolithiasis.
  • Higher risk of renal cell carcinoma and Wilms tumor
  • Radiological diagnosis is by intravenous pyelogram which shows "flower vase" sign or "hand shake" sign

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with burn injury. He is covered with burns on his head&neck,  both upper limbs, front and back of the chest. Calculate the percentage of burns.
questions.solution:
The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 45% according to Wallace’s rule of nine.

Calculation:

  • Burns on the head&neck would account for 9% of burns.
  • Burns on both upper limbs (9% for each limb) would add to 18%  
  • Burns on both sides of the chest would account for 18%

Therefore the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 9+18+18 = 45%

questions.text: In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate should exceed?
questions.solution:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed 60%. This coincides with every couple having 2 children.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index:

  • The pearl index is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).
  • Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure
  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that is used as the numerator must include every known conception, whatever its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher order births.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman had an episode of tonic-clonic seizure after which she was brought to the emergency department. On examination, the patient is febrile and appears slightly confused. Neurologic and physical examination findings are normal. Laboratory test results are as below, and the peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

Investigations report:

Hemoglobin: 7.8 g/dL, Platelet count: 45000/mm3

Leukocyte count: 9000/mm3
PT: 12 seconds
aPTT: 35 seconds
Serum creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Therapeutic plasma exchange is the treatment of choice and is the next best step in the management of this patient for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

The laboratory tests show anaemia and thrombocytopenia. Leukocyte count, PT, and aPTT are normal. Serum creatinine is elevated. The peripheral smear shows schistocytes on the blood smear. Also, the patient is febrile and has neurological manifestations like confusion and seizures.

The classic symptoms of TTP are the pentad of fever, thrombocytopenia, MAHA, neurologic abnormalities, and renal failure and the patient has all of these findings.

Other options:

  • Red blood cell transfusion may sometimes be indicated, however, it does not address the underlying pathogenesis of TTP.
  • Platelets are contraindicated because of the possibility of worsening the TTP.
  • Hemodialysis is indicated only If there is severe renal impairment. 

Note: TTP is a distinct entity and not the same as ITP
